summary.long: Genesis is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The earth was undeveloped and empty. Darkness covered the surface of the deep, and the Spirit of God was hovering over the surface of the waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let there be light,” and there was light.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God saw that the light was good. He separated the light from the darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God called the light “day,” and the darkness he called “night.” There was evening and there was morning—the first day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let there be an expanse between the waters, and let it separate the water from the water.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God made the expanse, and he separated the water that was below the expanse from the water that was above the expanse, and it was so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God called the expanse “sky.” There was evening and there was morning—the second day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let the waters under the sky be gathered together to one place, and let the dry land appear,” and it was so. ⎣The waters under the sky gathered to their own places, and the dry land appeared.⎦
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God called the dry ground “land,” and the gathering places of the waters he called “seas.” God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let the earth produce plants—vegetation that produces seed, and trees that bear fruit with its seed in it—each according to its own kind on the earth,” and it was so.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The earth brought forth plants, vegetation that produces seed according to its own kind, and trees that bear fruit with its seed in it, each according to its own kind, and God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was evening and there was morning—the third day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let there be lights in the expanse of the sky to divide the day from the night, and let them serve as markers to indicate seasons, days, and years.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Let them serve as lights in the expanse of the sky to give light to the earth,” and it was so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God made the two great lights: the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night. He also made the stars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God set these lights in place in the expanse of the sky to provide light for the earth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkness. God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was evening and there was morning—the fourth day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let the waters swarm with living creatures, and let birds and other winged creatures fly above the earth in the open expanse of the sky.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God created the large sea creatures and every living creature that moves, with which the waters swarm, according to their own kind, and every winged bird according to its own kind. God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God blessed them when he said, “Be fruitful and multiply. Fill the waters of the seas, and let birds multiply on the earth.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: There was evening and there was morning—the fifth day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let the earth produce living creatures according to their own kind, livestock, creeping things, and wild animals according to their own kind,” and it was so.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God made the wild animals according to their own kind, and the livestock according to their own kind, and everything that creeps on the ground according to its own kind. God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let us make man in our image, according to our likeness, and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the birds of the sky, and over the livestock, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that crawls on the earth.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
God created the man in his own image.
In the image of God he created him.
Male and female he created them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God blessed them and said to them, “Be fruitful, multiply, fill the earth, and subdue it. Have dominion over the fish of the sea, over the birds of the sky, and over every living thing that moves on the earth.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God said, “Look, I have given you every plant that produces seed on the face of the whole earth, and every tree that bears fruit that produces seed. It will be your food.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: To every animal of the earth, and to every bird of the sky, and to everything that creeps on the earth, in which there is the breath of life, I have given every green plant for food.” And it was so.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God saw everything that he had made, and indeed, it was very good. There was evening and there was morning—the sixth day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The heavens and the earth were finished, along with everything in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the seventh day God had finished his work that he had done, and he rested on the seventh day from all his work that he had been doing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God blessed the seventh day and set it apart as holy, because on it he rested from all his work of creation that he had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account about the development of the heavens and the earth when they were created, in the day that the Lord God made the earth and the heavens:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No bushes that grow in the field were yet on the earth, and no plants of the field had yet sprung up, since the Lord God had not yet caused it to rain on the earth. There was not yet a man to till the soil,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but water came up from the earth and watered the entire surface of the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God formed the man from the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God planted a garden in Eden in the east, and there he put the man whom he had formed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Out of the ground the Lord God made every kind of tree grow—trees that are pleasant to look at and good for food, including the Tree of Life in the middle of the garden and the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A river went out from Eden to water the garden, and from there it divided and became the headwaters of four rivers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of the first river is Pishon. It flows through the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the gold of that land is good. Incense and onyx stone are also found there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of the second river is Gihon. It is the same river that winds through the whole land of Cush.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of the third river is Tigris. This is the one which flows along the east side of Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God took the man and settled him in the Garden of Eden to work it and to take care of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God gave a command to the man. He said, “You may freely eat from every tree in the garden,
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: but you shall not eat from the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil, for on the day that you eat from it, you will certainly die.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The Lord God said, “It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper who is a suitable partner for him.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Out of the soil the Lord God had formed every wild animal and every bird of the sky, and he brought them to the man to see what he would call them. Whatever the man called every living creature, that became its name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man gave names to all the livestock, and to the birds of the sky, and to every wild animal, but for Adam no helper was found who was a suitable partner for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God caused the man to fall into a deep sleep. As the man slept, the Lord God took a rib and closed up the flesh where it had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God built a woman from the rib that he had taken from the man and brought her to the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The man said,
Now this one is bone of my bones
and flesh of my flesh.
She will be called “woman,”
because she was taken out of man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For this reason a man will leave his father and his mother
and will remain united with his wife,
and they will become one flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were both naked, the man and his wife, and they were not ashamed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the serpent was more clever than any wild animal which the Lord God had made. He said to the woman, “Has God really said, ‘You shall not eat from any tree in the garden’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said to the serpent, “We may eat fruit from the trees of the garden,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but not from the fruit of the tree that is in the middle of the garden. God has said, ‘You shall not eat from it. You shall not touch it, or else you will die.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The serpent said to the woman, “You certainly will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, God knows that the day you eat from it, your eyes will be opened, and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman saw that the tree was good for food, and that it was appealing to the eyes, and that the tree was desirable to make one wise, she took some of its fruit and ate. She gave some also to her husband, who was with her, and he ate it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The eyes of both of them were opened, and they realized that they were naked. They sewed fig leaves together and made coverings for their waists.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They heard the voice of the Lord God, who was walking around in the garden during the cooler part of the day, and the man and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the Lord God among the trees of the garden.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God called to the man and said to him, “Where are you?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The man said, “I heard your voice in the garden, and I was afraid, because I was naked, so I hid myself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Who told you that you were naked? Have you eaten from the tree from which I commanded you not to eat?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The man said, “The woman you gave to be with me—she gave me fruit from the tree, and I ate it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord God said to the woman, “What have you done?”
The woman said, “The serpent deceived me, and I ate.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
The Lord God said to the serpent:
Because you have done this,
you are cursed more than all the livestock,
and more than every wild animal.
You shall crawl on your belly,
and you shall eat dust all the days of your life.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
I will put hostility between you and the woman,
and between your seed and her seed.
He will crush your head,
and you will crush his heel.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
To the woman he said:
I will greatly increase your pain in childbearing.
With painful labor you will give birth to children.
Your desire will be for your husband,
but he will rule over you.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
To Adam he said:
Because you listened to your wife’s voice
and ate from the tree about which I commanded you,
“You shall not eat from it,”
the soil is cursed on account of you.
You will eat from it with painful labor all the days of your life.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
Thorns and thistles will spring up from the ground for you,
but you will eat the crops of the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By the sweat of your face you will eat bread
until you return to the soil,
for out of it you were taken.
For you are dust,
and to dust you shall return.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The man named his wife Eve because she would be the mother of all the living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God made clothing of animal skins for Adam and for his wife and clothed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God said, “Look, the man has become like one of us, knowing good and evil. Now, so that he does not reach out his hand and also take from the Tree of Life and eat and live forever—”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: the Lord God sent him out from the Garden of Eden to work the soil from which he had been taken.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So he drove the man out, and in front of the Garden of Eden he stationed cherubim and a flaming sword, which turned in every direction to guard the way to the Tree of Life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man was intimate with Eve, his wife. She conceived and gave birth to Cain. She said, “I have gotten a man with the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She also gave birth to Cain’s brother Abel.
Abel tended sheep, but Cain worked the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As time passed, one day Cain brought an offering to the Lord from the fruit of the soil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abel also brought some of the firstborn of his flock and their fat portions. The Lord looked favorably on Abel and his offering,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but he did not look favorably on Cain and his offering. Cain was very angry, and his face showed it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Cain, “Why are you angry? Why do you have that angry look on your face?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you do good, will you not be lifted up? If you do not do good, sin is crouching at the door. It has a strong desire for you, but you must rule over it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cain said to Abel, his brother, “Let’s go into the field.” When they were in the field, Cain attacked Abel, his brother, and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to Cain, “Where is Abel, your brother?”
He said, “I don’t know. Am I my brother’s keeper?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood is crying to me from the soil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you are cursed and sent away from the soil which has opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you work the soil, it will no longer give its strength to you. You shall be a fugitive and a wanderer on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cain said to the Lord, “My punishment is too great for me to bear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, today you have driven me away from the soil. I will be hidden from your face, and I will be a fugitive and a wanderer on the earth. And whoever finds me will kill me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “No! If anyone kills Cain, he will face sevenfold revenge.” And the Lord appointed a sign for Cain, so that anyone who found him would not strike him down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cain went out from the Lord’s presence and lived in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cain was intimate with his wife. She conceived and gave birth to Enoch. Cain built a city and named the city after his son Enoch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Enoch, Irad was born. Irad became the father of Mehujael. Mehujael became the father of Methushael. Methushael became the father of Lamech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lamech took two wives. The name of one was Adah, and the name of the other was Zillah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adah gave birth to Jabal, who was the predecessor of those who dwell in tents and have livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brother’s name was Jubal, who was the predecessor of all who play the lyre and flute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zillah also gave birth to Tubal Cain, who made all kinds of tools and weapons from bronze and iron. Tubal Cain’s sister was Na’amah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lamech said to his wives:
Adah and Zillah, hear my voice.
You wives of Lamech, listen to my speech.
Look, I have killed a man for wounding me,
a young man for bruising me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If Cain will be avenged seven times,
then Lamech will be avenged seventy-seven times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adam was intimate with his wife again. She gave birth to a son and named him Seth, because she said, “God has set another child in place of Abel for me, since Cain killed him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later a son was born to Seth, and he named him Enosh. This is when people began to proclaim the name of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account about the development of Adam’s family:
In the day that God created man, he made him in the likeness of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He created them male and female and blessed them, and on the day they were created, he named them “mankind.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adam lived 130 years, and he became the father of a son in his own likeness, according to his own image, and he named him Seth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The days of Adam after he became the father of Seth were 800 years, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days that Adam lived were 930 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seth lived 105 years, and he became the father of Enosh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seth lived 807 years after he became the father of Enosh, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Seth were 912 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enosh lived 90 years, and he became the father of Kenan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enosh lived 815 years after he became the father of Kenan, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Enosh were 905 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kenan lived 70 years, and he became the father of Mahalalel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kenan lived 840 years after he became the father of Mahalalel, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Kenan were 910 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mahalalel lived 65 years, and he became the father of Jared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mahalalel lived 830 years after he became the father of Jared, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Mahalalel were 895 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jared lived 162 years, and he became the father of Enoch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jared lived 800 years after he became the father of Enoch, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Jared were 962 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enoch lived 65 years, and he became the father of Methuselah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he became the father of Methuselah, Enoch walked with God 300 years, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Enoch were 365 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enoch walked with God. Then, he was not there, for God took him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Methuselah lived 187 years, and he became the father of Lamech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he became the father of Lamech, Methuselah lived 782 years, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Methuselah were 969 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lamech lived 182 years and became the father of a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He named him Noah and said, “This one will bring us comfort during our work and the hard labor that we must perform with our hands because the Lord has cursed the soil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lamech lived 595 years after he became father of Noah, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Lamech were 777 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah was 500 years old, and Noah became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what happened when mankind began to multiply on the face of the earth.
When daughters were born to people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the sons of God saw that the daughters of men were beautiful, and they took as wives for themselves any of them they chose.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, “My Spirit will not struggle with man forever, because he is only flesh. His days will be 120 years.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Nephilim were on the earth in those days. After that, the sons of God went to the daughters of men, who bore children for them. Those became the powerful, famous men of ancient times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord saw that the wickedness of mankind was great on the earth, and that all the thoughts and plans they formed in their hearts were only evil every day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord regretted that he had made man on the earth, and his heart was filled with sorrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, “I will wipe out mankind, whom I have created, from the face of the earth, along with the animals, the creeping things, and the birds of the sky, because I regret that I have made them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Noah found favor in the eyes of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account about the development of Noah’s family.
Noah was a righteous man, a man of integrity in that generation. Noah walked with God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah became the father of three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the sight of God the earth was morally corrupt, and the earth was filled with violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God looked at the earth and saw that it was corrupt, for all flesh was corrupt in all their ways on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God said to Noah, “I have decreed the end of all flesh, because the earth is filled with violence because of them. Now I am going to destroy them along with the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Make an ark of gopher wood. Make rooms in the ark. Seal it inside and outside with pitch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how you are to make it: The length of the ark is to be 450 feet, its width 75 feet, and its height 45 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make a roof for the ark, and leave an eighteen-inch opening just under the roof. Place a door on the side of the ark. Make it with lower, second, and third decks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I myself am about to bring a flood of waters on the earth, in order to destroy all flesh under the sky that has the breath of life. Everything that is on the earth will die,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but I will establish my covenant with you. You shall come into the ark—you, your sons, your wife, and your sons’ wives with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall bring a pair (male and female) of every kind of living flesh into the ark with you to keep them alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Include the birds according to their kinds, the livestock according to their kinds, every creeping thing on the ground according to their kinds. Two of every sort shall come to you, so you can keep them alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take with you every type of food that is eaten, and store it for yourself, so it can be used as food for you and for them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that is what Noah did. He did everything that God commanded him, just as he had been told.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Noah, “Come into the ark, you and your entire household, for I have seen that you are righteous before me in this generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From every clean animal take with you seven pairs, a male and his female. From the animals that are not clean, take two, a male and his female.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also from the ⎣clean⎦ birds of the sky take seven and seven, male and female, ⎣and of all the unclean birds, one pair, a male and a female⎦ to keep their offspring alive on the face of the whole earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In seven days I will cause it to rain on the earth for forty days and forty nights. Every living thing that I have made, I will wipe off the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah did everything that the Lord commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah was six hundred years old when the flood came, and water covered the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah went into the ark with his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives, because of the waters of the flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Clean animals, animals that are not clean, birds, and everything that creeps on the ground
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: went into the ark with Noah two by two (male and female), just as God had commanded Noah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After seven days, the waters of the flood came on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month, on that very day, all the fountains of the great deep burst open, and the floodgates of the sky were opened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rain came down on the earth for forty days and forty nights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that same day Noah, Noah’s sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth, Noah’s wife, and the three wives of his sons along with them entered the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went in with every animal according to its kind, all the livestock according to their kinds, every creeping thing that creeps on the earth according to its kind, and everything that flies according to its kind, flying birds of every sort.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pairs of all the animals that have the breath of life in them went to Noah in the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A male and female of each animal that breathes went in, just as God had commanded Noah. Then the Lord shut Noah in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The flood kept coming on the earth for forty days. The waters became deeper and lifted up the ark until it floated high above the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The water kept increasing and overwhelmed the earth, and the ark was carried along on the surface of the water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The water overwhelmed the earth. All the high mountains that were under the entire sky were covered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters rose more than twenty feet above the mountains and covered them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All living creatures that moved on the earth perished, including birds, livestock, wild animals, every creeping thing that crawls on the earth, and all mankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything that breathed the breath of life through its nostrils, that is, everything that was on the dry land, died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every living thing that was on the face of the earth was wiped out, including mankind, livestock, creeping things, and birds of the sky. They all were wiped off the earth. Only Noah was left, as well as those who were with him in the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters overwhelmed the earth for one hundred fifty days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God remembered Noah, as well as all the animals and all the livestock that were with him in the ark. So God caused a wind to pass over the earth, and the waters subsided.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fountains of the deep and the floodgates of the sky were also closed, and the rain from the sky was restrained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters kept receding from the earth. After the end of one hundred fifty days the waters had decreased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month, the ark came to rest on the mountains of Ararat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters receded continuously until the tenth month. In the tenth month, on the first day of the month, the tops of the mountains were visible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then at the end of forty days Noah opened the window he had made in the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent out a raven, and it kept flying back and forth, until the waters were dried up from the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he sent out a dove to see if the waters had receded from the surface of the ground,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the dove found no place to rest its foot, and it returned to him in the ark, because there was water on the surface of the whole earth. Noah reached out his hand, took the dove, and brought it back to him in the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He waited another seven days. Then he sent the dove out of the ark again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The dove came back to him at evening, and there in its mouth was an olive leaf it had just plucked. So Noah knew that the waters had receded from the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He waited another seven days and sent the dove out again. This time it did not return to him anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so in the six hundred first year, in the first month, on the first day of the month, the waters were dried up from the earth. Noah removed the covering of the ark and looked out. He saw that the surface of the ground was dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth was dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God spoke to Noah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go out of the ark—you, your wife, your sons, and your sons’ wives with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring out with you every living thing of every sort that is with you, all flesh, including birds, livestock, and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth, so that they may swarm over the earth, and be fruitful and multiply on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah went out with his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives along with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every animal, every creeping thing, every bird, and whatever swarms on the earth went out of the ship, species by species.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah built an altar to the Lord and took from every clean animal and every clean bird and offered burnt offerings on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord smelled the pleasant aroma. The Lord said in his heart, “I will never again curse the soil anymore because of man, for the thoughts he forms in his heart are evil from his youth. Neither will I ever again strike every living thing, as I have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the earth remains, seedtime and harvest, cold and heat, summer and winter, and day and night shall not cease.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God blessed Noah and his sons and said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every animal on the earth and every bird in the sky will fear you and dread you. Everything that swarms on the ground and all the fish in the sea are handed over to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every living, moving thing will be food for you. I have given everything to you, just as I gave you the green plants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But flesh that has the blood (which is its life) still in it, you shall not eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, I will hold each animal and each person responsible for your lifeblood. I will hold each man responsible for the life of his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever sheds man’s blood, by man his blood shall be shed, for God made man in his own image.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But you, be fruitful and multiply. Increase abundantly on the earth, and multiply on it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to Noah and to his sons, who were with him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Listen, I will now establish my covenant with you and with your descendants after you
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and with everything with you that has the breath of life: with the birds, with the livestock, and with every wild animal that is on the earth with you, with everything that went out of the ark, even with every wild animal on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will establish my covenant with you: Never again will all living creatures be cut off by the waters of a flood. Neither will there ever again be a flood to destroy the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God also said, “This is the sign of the covenant between me and you and every living creature with you that I am giving for all generations to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have set my rainbow in the cloud, and it will be the sign of a covenant between me and the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever I bring a cloud over the earth and the rainbow is seen in the cloud,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will remember my covenant, which is between me and you and every living creature of every sort, and the waters will never again become a flood to destroy all flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rainbow will be in the cloud. I will look at it so that I may remember the everlasting covenant between God and every living creature of every kind that is on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to Noah, “This is the sign of the covenant that I have established between me and all flesh that is on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Noah who went out from the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. (Ham was the father of Canaan.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These three were the sons of Noah, and from these, people spread out over the whole earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah began to be a man of the soil and planted a vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He drank some of the wine and got drunk. He lay uncovered inside his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ham, the father of Canaan, saw the nakedness of his father and told his two brothers outside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shem and Japheth took a garment and laid it over their shoulders. They went in backwards and covered the nakedness of their father. They faced backwards, and they did not see their father’s nakedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah awoke from his wine and knew what his youngest son had done to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said:
A curse on Canaan!
He will be the lowest of servants to his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he said:
Blessed be the Lord, the God of Shem!
Let Canaan be his servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May God enlarge Japheth.
Let him dwell in the tents of Shem.
Let Canaan be his servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah lived 350 years after the flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the days of Noah were 950 years. Then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now this is the account about the development of groups of people who descended from Shem, Ham, and Japheth, the sons of Noah. Sons were born to them after the flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshek, and Tiras.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, the Kittim, and the Dodanim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The islands and coastlands were divided into different lands among these peoples on the basis of their languages, their ethnic groups, and their nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Ham were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Ra’amah, and Sabteca.
The sons of Ra’amah were Sheba and Dedan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cush became the father of Nimrod. He was the first to be a mighty warrior on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was a mighty hunter before the Lord. That is why the saying is “Like Nimrod, a mighty hunter before the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The beginning of his kingdom was Babel, Uruk, Akkad, and Calneh in the land of Shinar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From that land he went to Assyria and built Nineveh, Rehoboth Ir, Calah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Resen between Nineveh and Calah, the great city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mizraim became the father of the Ludim, Anamim, Lehabim, Naphtuhim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pathrusim, Casluhim (from whom the Philistines descended), and the Caphtorim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Canaan became the father of Sidon (his firstborn) and Heth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as well as the Jebusites, the Amorites, the Girgashites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Hivites, the Arkites, the Sinites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Arvadites, the Zemarites, and the Hamathites. Afterward the families of the Canaanites spread out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the borders of the Canaanites extended from Sidon, southward toward Gerar, as far as Gaza; from there it extended eastward toward Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboiim, as far as Lasha.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Ham, according to their ethnic groups, their languages, their lands, and their nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sons were also born to Shem, the older brother of Japheth, the father of all the descendants of Eber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Aram were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Arphaxad became the father of Shelah. Shelah became the father of Eber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To Eber two sons were born. The name of one was Peleg, because in his days the earth was divided.
Eber’s brother’s name was Joktan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joktan became the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were the sons of Joktan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their dwelling was from Mesha all the way to Sephar, in the hill country of the east.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the descendants of Shem according to their ethnic groups, their languages, their lands, and their nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the families and groups of peoples descended from the sons of Noah, according to their genealogies, by their nations. From these, nations spread out over the earth after the flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole earth had one language and a single vocabulary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As people traveled in the east, they found a plain in the land of Shinar, and they settled there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to one another, “Come, let’s make bricks and bake them thoroughly.” They used mud brick instead of stone for building material, and they used tar for mortar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “Come, let’s build a city for ourselves and a tower whose top reaches to the sky, and let’s make a name for ourselves, so that we will not be scattered abroad over the face of the whole earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord came down to see the city and the tower that the people were building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, “If this is the first thing they are doing as one people, who all have one language, then nothing that they intend to do will be too difficult for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, let’s go down there and confuse their language, so that they cannot understand one another’s speech.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord scattered them from there over the face of the whole earth, and they stopped building the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was named Babel, because there the Lord confused the language of the whole earth. From there the Lord scattered them over the face of the whole earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account about the development of the family of Shem.
Shem was 100 years old and became the father of Arphaxad two years after the flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shem lived 500 years after he became the father of Arphaxad, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Arphaxad lived 35 years and became the father of Shelah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Arphaxad lived 403 years after he became the father of Shelah, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shelah lived 30 years and became the father of Eber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shelah lived 403 years after he became the father of Eber, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eber lived 34 years and became the father of Peleg.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eber lived 430 years after he became the father of Peleg, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Peleg lived 30 years and became the father of Reu.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Peleg lived 209 years after he became the father of Reu, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reu lived 32 years and became the father of Serug.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reu lived 207 years after he became the father of Serug, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Serug lived 30 years and became the father of Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Serug lived 200 years after he became the father of Nahor, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nahor lived 29 years and became the father of Terah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nahor lived 119 years after he became the father of Terah, and he became the father of sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Terah lived 70 years and became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now this is the account about the development of the family of Terah.
Terah became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran. Haran became the father of Lot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Haran died before his father Terah. He died in the land of his birth, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram and Nahor took wives. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah, the daughter of Haran, who was also the father of Iscah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarai was barren. She had no child.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Terah took his son Abram, his grandson Lot, who was the son of Haran, and his daughter-in-law Sarai, who was the wife of his son Abram, and they set out from Ur of the Chaldeans to go into the land of Canaan. They came to Haran and lived there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The days of Terah were 205 years. Terah died in Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord said to Abram, “Get out of your country and away from your relatives and from your father’s house and go to the land that I will show you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make you a great nation. I will bless you and make your name great. You will be a blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bless those who bless you, and I will curse anyone who dishonors you. All of the families of the earth will be blessed in you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abram went, as the Lord had told him. Lot went with him. Abram was seventy-five years old when he departed from Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram took Sarai his wife, Lot his brother’s son, and all the possessions they had accumulated and the people that they had acquired in Haran, and they set out to travel to the land of Canaan. Eventually they arrived in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram passed through the land until he came to the Oak of Moreh at the place called Shechem. The Canaanites were in the land at that time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to Abram and said, “I will give this land to your descendants.” Abram built an altar there to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He moved on from there to the hill country east of Bethel and pitched his tent there, with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east. There he built an altar to the Lord and proclaimed the name of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram pulled out from there and kept traveling toward the Negev.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a famine in the land. So Abram went down into Egypt to stay there for a while, because the famine was severe in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he was about to enter Egypt, he said to Sarai his wife, “Look, I know that you are a beautiful woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It might happen that when the Egyptians see you, they will say, ‘This is his wife.’ Then they will kill me, but they will keep you alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please say that you are my sister, so that it will go well for me because of you, and that my life may be preserved on account of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So it happened that when Abram arrived in Egypt, the Egyptians did see that the woman was very beautiful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s officials saw her and praised her to Pharaoh, and the woman was taken into Pharaoh’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He treated Abram well for her sake. Abram received sheep, cattle, male donkeys, male servants, female servants, female donkeys, and camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord struck Pharaoh and his house with severe diseases because of Sarai, Abram’s wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh summoned Abram and said, “What is this that you have done to me? Why didn’t you tell me that she was your wife?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you say, ‘She is my sister,’ so that I took her to be my wife? Here is your wife. Take her and go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh gave his men orders concerning him, so they sent him on his way with his wife and all that he had.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram went up out of Egypt into the Negev. He went with his wife and with all that he had, and with Lot too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram was very wealthy in livestock, in silver, and in gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went on his journeys from the Negev to Bethel, to the place where his tent had been at the beginning, between Bethel and Ai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went to the site of the altar that he had made there earlier. There Abram proclaimed the name of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lot, who went with Abram, also had flocks, herds, and tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land was not able to support them if they lived close together, because their possessions were so great that they could not live together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was conflict between the herdsmen of Abram’s livestock and the herdsmen of Lot’s livestock. (The Canaanites and the Perizzites lived in the land at that time.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram said to Lot, “Please, because we are close relatives, let there be no conflict between me and you and between my herdsmen and your herdsmen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Doesn’t the whole land lie before you? Please separate yourself from me. If you go to the left, then I will go to the right. Or if you go to the right, then I will go to the left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lot looked up and saw the whole region around the Jordan River as you come to Zoar. (Before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah, it was well watered everywhere, like the garden of the Lord, like the land of Egypt.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Lot chose the region around the Jordan for himself. Lot headed out toward the east, and they separated from each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram lived in the land of Canaan, and Lot lived among the cities of the region around the Jordan and moved his tent close to Sodom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the men of Sodom were extremely wicked sinners against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Lot was separated from him, the Lord said to Abram, “Now, lift up your eyes, and look around from the place where you are. Look north and south, east and west,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because all the land that you see, I will give to you and to your descendants permanently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make your descendants like the dust of the earth, so that if a man could count the dust of the earth, then your descendants could also be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get up, walk through the length and breadth of the land, because I will give it to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram moved his tent and went to live by the oaks at Mamre, which are at Hebron, and built an altar there to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Kedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of Goyim
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: made war against Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these joined together in the Valley of Siddim (that is, the Salt Sea).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For twelve years they served Kedorlaomer, but in the thirteenth year they rebelled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourteenth year Kedorlaomer and the kings who were with him came and struck the Rephaites in Ashteroth Karnaim, the Zuzites in Ham, the Emites in Shaveh Kiriathaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Horites in their Mount Seir, all the way to El Paran, which is by the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They returned and came to En Mishpat (that is, Kadesh) and struck all the territory of the Amalekites, and also the Amorites who lived in Hazazon Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Sodom, the king of Gomorrah, the king of Admah, the king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar) went out and lined up for battle in the Valley of Siddim
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: against Kedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of Goyim, Amraphel king of Shinar, and Arioch king of Ellasar—four kings against five.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Valley of Siddim was full of tar pits. When the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, they fell there. Those who survived fled to the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The raiders took all the possessions of Sodom and Gomorrah and all their food, and then they went on their way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because he had been living in Sodom, they took also Lot, the son of Abram’s brother, and his possessions and went on their way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One person escaped and came and told Abram the Hebrew, who was living by the oaks that belonged to Mamre the Amorite, the brother of Eshcol and Aner. They were allies of Abram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abram heard that his relative was taken captive, he led out all his trained men who were born in his house, three hundred eighteen of them, and pursued them as far as Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night he divided his servants into groups to attack them. He struck them and pursued them to Hobah, north of Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought back all the possessions. He also brought back his relative Lot, and his possessions, and the women also, and the rest of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Abram’s return from the defeat of Kedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, the king of Sodom went out to meet him at the Valley of Shaveh (that is, the King’s Valley).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Melchizedek king of Salem brought out bread and wine. He was a priest of God Most High.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He blessed Abram and said, “Blessed be Abram by God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and blessed be God Most High, who has delivered your enemies into your hand.”
Abram gave him a tenth of everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Sodom said to Abram, “Give me the people and take the goods for yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram said to the king of Sodom, “I have lifted up my hand to swear to the Lord, God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that I will not take a thread or a sandal strap or anything that is yours, so that you cannot say, ‘I have made Abram rich.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take nothing except that which the young men have eaten and the share belonging to the men who went with me, namely, Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre. Let them take their share.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these events the word of the Lord came to Abram in a vision. He said, “Do not be afraid, Abram. I am your shield, your very great reward.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram said, “Lord God what can you give me, since I remain childless, and the one who will inherit my estate is Eliezer of Damascus?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram also said, “Look, you have given me no offspring, so a servant born in my house will be my heir.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then, the word of the Lord came to him. God said, “This man will not be your heir, but instead one who will come out of your own body will be your heir.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord then brought him outside and said, “Now look toward the sky and count the stars, if you are able to count them.” He said to Abram, “This is what your descendants will be like.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram believed in the Lord, and the Lord credited it to him as righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to him, “I am the Lord, who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans to give you this land as a possession.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Lord God, how will I know that I will possess it?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “Bring me a heifer three years old, a female goat three years old, a ram three years old, a turtledove, and a young pigeon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram gathered all of these, divided them in half, and laid the two halves across from each other, but he did not divide the birds in two.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Birds of prey came down on the carcasses, but Abram drove them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sun was going down, a deep sleep fell on Abram. Then terrifying, deep darkness fell on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Abram, “Know this! Your descendants will live as aliens in a land that is not theirs, and they will serve its people, who will afflict them for four hundred years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will surely judge the nation that they will serve. Afterward your descendants will come out with great wealth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but you will go to your fathers in peace. You will be buried at a good old age.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourth generation your descendants will come here again, because the guilt of the Amorites is not yet full.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then when the sun had gone down and it was dark, suddenly a smoking oven and a flaming torch passed between the pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day the Lord made a covenant with Abram. He said, “To your descendants I have given this land from the river of Egypt to the great river, the river Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give you the territory of the Kenites, the Kenizzites, the Kadmonites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Rephaites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Girgashites, and the Jebusites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Sarai, Abram’s wife, bore no children for him. She had a servant girl, an Egyptian, whose name was Hagar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarai said to Abram, “See now, the Lord has prevented me from bearing children. Please go to my servant girl. It may be that I can build up a family through her.” Abram listened to the voice of Sarai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Abram had lived ten years in the land of Canaan, Sarai, Abram’s wife, took her servant girl, Hagar the Egyptian, and gave her to her husband Abram to be his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went to Hagar, and she conceived. When she saw that she had conceived, she looked down on her mistress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarai said to Abram, “This wrong that I am suffering is on account of you. I gave my servant girl into your embrace, and when she saw that she had conceived, she looked down on me. May the Lord judge between me and you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abram said to Sarai, “Look, your servant girl is in your hands. Do to her whatever seems good to you.” Sarai dealt harshly with her, and she fled from her presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Angel of the Lord found Hagar beside a flowing spring in the wilderness, beside the spring on the way to Shur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “Hagar, servant girl of Sarai, where did you come from? Where are you going?”
She said, “I am fleeing from the presence of my mistress Sarai.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Angel of the Lord said to her, “Return to your mistress and submit to her authority.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Angel of the Lord said to her, “I will greatly multiply your descendants, so that they will be too many to count.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Angel of the Lord said to her, “Listen, you are expecting a child and will give birth to a son. You shall name him Ishmael, because the Lord has heard your affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will be a wild donkey of a man. His hand will be against every man, and every man’s hand against him. He will dwell in hostility toward all of his brothers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She called the name of the Lord who spoke to her, “You are a God who sees,” for she said, “Here have I really seen him who sees me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore the well was called Be’er Lahai Roi. It is right there between Kadesh and Bered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hagar gave birth to a son for Abram. Abram named his son, whom Hagar bore, Ishmael.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore Ishmael for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abram was ninety-nine years old, the Lord appeared to Abram and said to him, “I am God Almighty. Walk before me and be blameless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make my covenant between me and you, and I will make your descendants very numerous.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram fell on his face. God spoke with him. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for me, this is my covenant with you. You will be the father of many nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your name will not be Abram anymore, but your name will be Abraham, for I have made you the father of a large group of nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make you extremely fruitful, and I will produce nations from you. Kings will come out of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will establish my covenant between me and you and your descendants after you as an everlasting covenant throughout their generations. I will be your God and the God of your descendants after you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give the land where you are living as an alien, all the land of Canaan, to you and to your descendants after you as a permanent possession. I will be their God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to Abraham, “As for you, you must keep my covenant, you and your descendants after you throughout their generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is my covenant, which you shall keep, a covenant between me and you and your descendants after you: Every male among you shall be circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall be circumcised by cutting the foreskin off your flesh. It will be a sign of the covenant between me and you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every boy among you who is eight days old shall be circumcised, every male throughout your generations, whether he is born in your house or purchased with money from any foreigner who is not descended from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every male who is born in your house or one who is purchased with your money must be circumcised. My covenant will be marked on your flesh as an everlasting covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The uncircumcised male who is not circumcised by removing the foreskin from his flesh, that person must be cut off from his people. He has broken my covenant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to Abraham, “As for Sarai your wife, you shall not call her Sarai anymore, but her name will be Sarah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bless her and even give you a son by her. Yes, I will bless her, and she will be a mother of nations. Kings of many peoples will come from her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham fell on his face and laughed and said in his heart, “Will a child be born to someone who is one hundred years old? Will Sarah, who is ninety years old, give birth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Abraham said to God, “Oh, let Ishmael live in your presence!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God said, “No, Sarah, your wife, will bear a son for you. You shall name him Isaac. I will establish my covenant with him as an everlasting covenant for his descendants after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for Ishmael, I have heard you. Yes, I have blessed him. I will make him fruitful and will multiply him very greatly. He will become the father of twelve chiefs, and I will make him into a great nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But my covenant I will establish with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear for you at this set time next year.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he finished talking with him, God went up from Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham took his son Ishmael, along with every male in Abraham’s house, all those who were born in his house, and all those who were purchased with his money, and he circumcised them by cutting off the foreskin from their flesh. He did this on that very day, just as God had said to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham was ninety-nine years old when the foreskin of his flesh was circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael, his son, was thirteen years old when the foreskin of his flesh was circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the same day both Abraham and Ishmael, his son, were circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of his house, those born in the house as well as those purchased with money from a foreigner, were circumcised along with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to Abraham by the oaks of Mamre, as he was sitting by the door to his tent during the heat of the day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham looked up, and he saw three men standing in front of him. When he saw them, he ran from the tent door to meet them, and he bowed down to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “My lord, if I have now found favor in your sight, please do not pass your servant by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now let me get a little water so that all of you can wash your feet and rest under the tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let me get some bread so that you can refresh yourselves. After that you may go your way. That is why you have come to your servant.”
They said, “Yes, do as you have said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham hurried into the tent to Sarah and said, “Quickly prepare twenty quarts of fine flour, knead it, and make some loaves of bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham ran to the herd, brought a good, tender calf, and gave it to the servant. He hurried to prepare it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took cheese curds, milk, and the calf that he had prepared and set it before them. He stood beside them under the tree while they ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They asked him, “Where is Sarah, your wife?”
He said, “She is over there in the tent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One of the men said, “I will certainly return to you when this season comes around next year. Then Sarah your wife will have a son.”
Sarah was listening to this from the tent door, which was behind him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abraham and Sarah were old, well into old age. Sarah was past the age for childbearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah laughed to herself, saying, “After I am worn out, will I have pleasure, since my lord is also old?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh and say, ‘Will I really give birth to a child though I am old?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is anything impossible for the Lord? At the set time next year I will return to you, and Sarah will have a son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Sarah denied it and said, “I did not laugh,” because she was afraid.
The Lord said, “Yes, you did laugh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men got up from there and looked down toward Sodom. Abraham went with them to see them on their way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, “Should I hide from Abraham what I am about to do,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: since Abraham will surely become a great and mighty nation, and all the nations of the earth will be blessed in him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have chosen him, so that he may command his children and his household who follow after him to keep the way of the Lord by carrying out righteousness and justice, so that the Lord may deliver to Abraham what he has promised him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said, “Because the outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is great, and because their sin is very flagrant,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will go down now and see if what they have done is as bad as the outcry that has come to me. If not, I will know.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two men turned from there and went toward Sodom, but Abraham remained standing before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham approached him and said, “Will you really sweep away the righteous along with the wicked?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What if there are fifty righteous people in the city? Will you really sweep them away and not spare the place for the sake of the fifty righteous who are in it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You would never do such a thing, killing the righteous along with the wicked, treating the righteous the same as the wicked. You would never do such a thing. The Judge of all the earth should do right, shouldn’t he?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, “If I find fifty righteous people within the city of Sodom, then I will spare the entire place for their sake.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham answered, “See now, I who am but dust and ashes have taken it on myself to speak to my Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What if there are five fewer than fifty righteous? Will you destroy the entire city if the number is five short?”
He said, “I will not destroy it if I find forty-five there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He spoke to him yet again and said, “What if only forty are found there?”
He said, “I will not do it for the sake of the forty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “Please, do not be angry, my Lord, but I will speak again. What if thirty are found there?”
He said, “I will not do it if I find thirty there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “See now, I have taken it upon myself to speak to my Lord. What if there are twenty found there?”
He said, “I will not destroy it for the sake of the twenty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “Please, do not be angry, my Lord, but I will speak just once more. What if ten are found there?”
He said, “I will not destroy it for the sake of the ten.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he had finished speaking with Abraham, the Lord went on his way, and Abraham returned to his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two angels came to Sodom at evening. Lot, who was sitting in the gatehouse of Sodom, saw them and got up to meet them. He bowed down with his face to the ground,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and he said, “See now, my lords, please turn aside into your servant’s house and spend the night. Wash your feet, and you can get up early and go on your way.”
They said, “No, we will spend the night in the street.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he kept urging them, so they came with him and entered his house. He made them a feast and baked unleavened bread, and they ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But before they lay down, the men of the city, the men of Sodom, surrounded the house, both young and old, all the people from all parts of town.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They called to Lot and said to him, “Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us, that we may be intimate with them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lot went out to them and shut the door behind him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Please, my brothers, do not act so wickedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See now, I have two daughters who have not had relations with a man. Please let me bring them out to you, and you may do to them whatever seems good to you. Only do not do anything to these men, because they have come under the protection of my roof.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “Get out of our way!” They also said, “This fellow came to live here as an alien, and now he appoints himself as a judge. Now we will treat you worse than them!” They kept pushing Lot back and were ready to break down the door.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the men inside reached out and grabbed Lot and pulled him into the house with them and shut the door.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They struck the men who were pressing against the door of the house, both young and old, with blindness so that they wore themselves out trying to find the door.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men said to Lot, “Do you have anyone else here? Sons-in-law, your sons, your daughters, whoever you have in the city, get them out of this place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for we are going to destroy this place, because the outcry against it has grown great before the Lord, so the Lord has sent us to destroy it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Lot went out and spoke to his sons-in-law, who were pledged to his daughters in marriage. He said, “Get up! Get out of this place, for the Lord is going to destroy the city.” But to his sons-in-law he seemed to be joking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the dawn came, the angels urged Lot, “Get going! Take your wife and your two daughters who are here, so that you will not be swept away by the guilt of the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Lot was taking too much time, so the men grabbed his hand, his wife’s hand, and the hands of his two daughters, because of the Lord’s compassion for him. They led him out and placed him outside of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then when they had taken them out, one of them said, “Run for your life! Don’t look behind you, and don’t stay anywhere in the plain. Escape to the mountains, so that you are not swept away!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lot said to them, “Oh no, my lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See now, your servant has found favor in your sight, and you have shown me great mercy by saving my life. I cannot flee to the mountains, or this disaster will stick with me, and I will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, this city is close enough to flee to, and it is a little one. Please let me flee there—isn’t it just a little one?—so that my life will be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man said to him, “Very well, I have granted your request concerning this thing, so I will not overthrow the city that you have spoken about.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hurry, flee there, because I cannot do anything until you get there.” So the city was named Zoar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sun had risen over the land when Lot came to Zoar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord rained on Sodom and Gomorrah sulfur and fire out of the sky from the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He overthrew those cities, as well as all the plain, all the inhabitants of the cities, and whatever grew in the soil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Lot’s wife, who was behind him, looked back, and she became a pillar of salt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham got up early in the morning and went to the place where he had stood before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He looked down toward Sodom and Gomorrah and all the land of the plain. As he looked, he saw that the smoke from the land was going up like the smoke from a kiln.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so when God destroyed the cities of the plain, God remembered Abraham and brought Lot out through the middle of the devastation, when he overthrew the cities where Lot had lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lot went up out of Zoar and lived in the mountains, for he was afraid to live in Zoar. His two daughters were with him. He lived in a cave with his two daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The firstborn said to the younger, “Our father is old, and there is not a man in the land to come to us as normally takes place everywhere on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come on, let’s get our father to drink wine, and we will lie down with him, that we may preserve our father’s seed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They got their father to drink wine that night, and the firstborn went and lay down with her father. He did not know it when she lay down or when she got up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the next day the firstborn said to the younger, “Look, last night I lay down with my father. Let us get him to drink wine again tonight. You go and lie down with him, so that we may preserve our father’s seed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They got their father to drink wine that night also. Then the younger went and lay with him. He did not know it when she lay down or when she got up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way both of Lot’s daughters became pregnant by their father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The firstborn gave birth to a son and named him Moab. He is the father of the Moabites to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The younger also gave birth to a son and called his name Ben Ammi. He is the father of the people of Ammon to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham traveled from there toward the Negev, and he lived between Kadesh and Shur. He lived as a resident alien in Gerar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About his wife Sarah Abraham said, “She is my sister.” Abimelek king of Gerar sent and took Sarah.
verses.speaker: Narrator
