verses.text: But God came to Abimelek in a dream during the night and said to him, “Listen to me! You are a dead man because of the woman you have taken, because she has a husband.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abimelek had not come near her. He said, “Lord, will you kill even a righteous nation?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Didn’t he tell me, ‘She is my sister’? Even she herself said, ‘He is my brother.’ I have done this with a sincere heart and innocent hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to him in the dream, “Yes, I know that you have done this with a sincere heart, so I also prevented you from sinning against me. That is why I did not allow you to touch her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore, return the man’s wife. He is a prophet, and he will pray for you, and you will live. If you do not return her, know for sure that you will die, you along with all who are yours.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek rose early in the morning, called all his servants, and told them all these things. The men were terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelek summoned Abraham and said to him, “What have you done to us? How have I sinned against you, that you have brought this great sin on me and on my kingdom? You have done things to me that should not be done!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek said to Abraham, “What did you see in us that made you do this?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said, “I did it because I said to myself, ‘Surely they do not fear God in this place. They will kill me to get my wife.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Besides, she really is my sister, the daughter of my father but not the daughter of my mother, and she became my wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When God had me migrate from my father’s house, I said to her, ‘This is the kindness that you shall show to me: Everywhere that we go, say about me, “He is my brother.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek took sheep and cattle, male servants and female servants, and he gave them to Abraham. He also returned Sarah, his wife, to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek said, “Look, my land is in front of you. Dwell wherever it pleases you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Sarah he said, “Look, I have given your brother a thousand pieces of silver. You see, it covers any offense in the eyes of everyone who is with you. In front of all of them you are vindicated.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham prayed to God. God healed Abimelek and his wife and his female servants, so that they were able to bear children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord had closed up tight all the wombs of the household of Abimelek over the matter of Sarah, Abraham’s wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord visited Sarah as he had said, and the Lord did for Sarah as he had promised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah conceived and gave birth to a son for Abraham in his old age, at the set time which God had announced to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham named the son who was born to him—the son whom Sarah had borne to him— Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham circumcised his son Isaac when he was eight days old, as God had commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah said, “God has made me laugh. Everyone who hears will laugh with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne a son for him in his old age.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The child grew and was weaned. Abraham made a great feast on the day that Isaac was weaned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah saw the son of Hagar the Egyptian, the son whom Hagar had borne to Abraham, laughing at Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, she said to Abraham, “Throw out this slave girl and her son! For the son of this slave will not be heir with my son Isaac.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham was very distressed because of his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to Abraham, “Do not be so distressed because of the boy and because of your maid. Listen to everything that Sarah says to you, because the family line of your descendants will be traced through Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will also make the son of the maid into a nation because he too is your offspring.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham got up early in the morning. He took bread and a waterskin, which he gave to Hagar, putting it over her shoulder. He sent her away with her child. She set out and wandered in the wilderness near Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The water in the skin was used up, and she dragged the child under one of the bushes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She went and sat down by herself, across from him, at a distance, about a bow shot away, because she said, “Do not let me see the death of the child.” She sat across from him and wept loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God heard the boy’s voice, and the Angel of God called to Hagar out of heaven and said to her, “What is wrong, Hagar? Do not be afraid, for God has heard the boy’s voice right where he is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get up. Help the boy up, and take him by the hand, because I will make him into a great nation.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God opened her eyes, and she saw a well with water in it. She went, filled the skin with water, and gave the boy a drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God was with the boy, and as he grew up, he lived in the wilderness and became an archer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He lived in the wilderness of Paran. His mother took a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Abimelek and Phicol, the commander of his army, spoke to Abraham. He said, “God is with you in everything that you do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now swear to me here by God that you will not deal treacherously with me, or with my son, or with my grandson. But just as I have been kind to you, you shall do the same for me and for the land in which you have lived as an alien.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said, “I will swear it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham complained to Abimelek because of a well which Abimelek’s servants had seized violently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek said, “I do not know who has done this. You did not tell me, and I did not hear about it until today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham took sheep and cattle and gave them to Abimelek. The two of them made a treaty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham set aside seven ewe lambs from the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek said to Abraham, “Why have you set these seven ewe lambs by themselves?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “You shall accept these seven ewe lambs from my hand as legal testimony that I have dug this well.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, he called that place Beersheba, because they both took an oath there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they made a treaty at Beersheba. Then Abimelek got up with Phicol, the commander of his army, and they returned into the land of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beersheba, and there he proclaimed the name of the Lord, the Eternal God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham lived as an alien in the land of the Philistines for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some time later God tested Abraham. He called to him, “Abraham!”
Abraham answered, “I am here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Now take your son, your only son, whom you love, Isaac, and go to the land of Moriah. Offer him there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains there, the one to which I direct you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham got up early in the morning, saddled his donkey, and took two of his young men with him, along with Isaac his son. Abraham split the wood for the burnt offering. Then he set out to go to the place that God had told him about.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day Abraham looked up and saw the place in the distance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said to his young men, “Stay here with the donkey. The boy and I will go on over there. We will worship, and then we will come back to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and loaded it on Isaac his son. He took the firepot and the knife in his hand. The two of them went on together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isaac spoke to Abraham his father and said, “My father?”
He said, “I am here, my son.”
He said, “Here are the fire and the wood, but where is the lamb for a burnt offering?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said, “God himself will provide the lamb for a burnt offering, my son.” So the two of them went on together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came to the place that God had told him about. Abraham built the altar there. He arranged the wood, tied up Isaac his son, and laid him on the altar on top of the wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham stretched out his hand and took the knife to slaughter his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Angel of the Lord called to him from heaven, “Abraham, Abraham!”
Abraham said, “I am here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Do not lay your hand on the boy. Do not do anything to him. For now I know that you fear God, because you have not withheld your son, your only son, from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham looked around and saw that behind him there was a ram caught in the thicket by its horns. Abraham went and took the ram and offered it up as a burnt offering instead of his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham called the name of that place “The Lord Will Provide.” So it is said to this day, “On the mountain of the Lord it will be provided.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Angel of the Lord called to Abraham a second time from heaven
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, “I have sworn by myself, declares the Lord, because you have done this thing and have not withheld your son, your only son,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bless you greatly, and I will multiply your descendants greatly, like the stars of the sky and like the sand on the seashore. Your descendants will take possession of the city gates of their enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In your seed all the nations of the earth will be blessed, because you have obeyed my voice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham returned to his young men, and they set out and traveled together to Beersheba. Abraham lived at Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time after these things Abraham was told, “Listen. Milcah also has borne children for your brother Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are Uz his firstborn, his brother Buz, Kemuel the father of Aram,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bethuel became the father of Rebekah. These eight sons Milcah bore for Nahor, Abraham’s brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nahor’s concubine, whose name was Reumah, also gave birth to Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Ma’akah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah lived one hundred twenty-seven years. That was the length of Sarah’s life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah died in Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan. Abraham went to mourn for Sarah and to weep for her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham got up from beside his deceased wife. He went and spoke to the descendants of Heth. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am an alien who has settled among you. Let me have a piece of property for a burial place among you where I may bury my dead in their final resting place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Heth answered Abraham,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Listen to us, my lord. You are a prince of God among us. Bury your dead in the best of our tombs. None of us will withhold his tomb from you. Bury your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham stood up and bowed down to the people of the land, that is, to the descendants of Heth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “If you have agreed that I may bury my dead in their final resting place, then listen to me, and speak to Ephron son of Zohar on my behalf,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that he gives me the Cave of Machpelah, which is at the end of the field that he owns. Let him give it to me for the full price so that I may own a burial site among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Ephron was sitting among the descendants of Heth. Ephron the Hittite responded to Abraham in the hearing of all the Hittites who were gathered at the city gate. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, my lord, listen to me. I give you the field, and I give you the cave that is in it. In the presence of my people I give it to you. Bury your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham bowed down before the people of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke to Ephron in the hearing of the people of the land. He said, “No, but if you are willing, please listen to me. I will give the money for the field. Accept it from me, and I will bury my dead there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ephron responded to Abraham,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My lord, listen to me. The land is worth four hundred shekels of silver, but what is that between me and you? Go ahead, bury your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham accepted Ephron’s offer, and Abraham weighed out to Ephron the price that Ephron had quoted to him in the hearing of the Hittites, four hundred shekels of silver, according to the current standard of the merchants at that time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the field of Ephron, which was in Machpelah, near Mamre—the field, the cave that was in it, and all the trees that were within the boundaries of the field were deeded
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to Abraham as his property. This was done in the presence of all the Hittites, who were assembled at the gate of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Abraham buried Sarah his wife in the cave in the field at Machpelah near Mamre (that is, Hebron), in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The field and the cave that is in it were deeded to Abraham by the descendants of Heth as his property to be used as a burial site.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham was very old, well into old age. The Lord had blessed Abraham in all things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said to his servant, the senior supervisor of his house, who was in charge of everything that he had, “Please put your hand under my thigh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must swear by the Lord, the God of heaven and the God of the earth, that you will not acquire a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, you shall go to my country and to my relatives and acquire a wife for my son Isaac.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant said to him, “What if the woman is not willing to follow me to this land? In that case, should I take your son back to the land that you came from?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said to him, “Let me make it very clear to you that you are not to take my son back there again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord, the God of heaven, took me away from my father’s house and from the land of my birth. He spoke to me and swore to me, saying, ‘I will give this land to your descendants.’ The Lord will send his angel ahead of you, so you shall find a wife for my son from there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the woman is not willing to follow you, you will be released from this oath. But under no circumstances shall you take my son back there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant took ten of his master’s camels and set out. He took a variety of goods from his master with him. He set out and went to Mesopotamia to the city of Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the camels kneel down by the well outside the city. It was evening, the time when women go out to draw water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “O Lord, the God of my master Abraham, please give me success this day, and show kindness to my master Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here I am, standing by the spring of water, and the daughters of the men of the city are coming out to draw water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let this be the test: The young lady to whom I say, ‘Please let down your water jar, so that I may drink,’ will say, ‘Drink, and I will also give your camels a drink.’ She will be the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac. This is how I will know that you have shown kindness to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before he had even finished speaking, out came Rebekah with her water jar on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel, who was the son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham’s brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young lady was very beautiful to look at, a virgin, who had never been intimate with any man. She went down to the spring, filled her water jar, and came up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant ran to meet her and said, “Please give me a drink, a little water from your water jar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “Drink, my lord.” She quickly let down her water jar into her hands and gave him a drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she was done giving him a drink, she said, “I will also draw water for your camels, until they have finished drinking.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She hurried and emptied her water jar into the trough, ran to the well again to draw more water, and drew water for all his camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man remained silent and watched her carefully to find out whether the Lord had made his journey successful or not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, when the camels were finished drinking, the man took a gold nose ring that weighed half a shekel and two gold bracelets that weighed ten shekels for her wrists.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he asked, “Whose daughter are you? Please tell me. Is there room for us to stay in your father’s house?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to him, “I am the daughter of Bethuel, the son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She also said to him, “We have both straw and enough feed and enough room for you to spend the night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man bowed his head and worshipped the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Blessed be the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who has not forsaken his mercy and faithfulness toward my master. Indeed, the Lord has guided me to the house of my master’s relatives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young lady ran and told her mother’s household about these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah had a brother whose name was Laban. Laban ran out to the spring to meet the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he saw the nose ring and the bracelets on his sister’s wrists, and after he heard the words from Rebekah his sister, who said, “This is what the man said to me,” he went to find the man. And there he was, standing next to the camels by the spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said, “Come with me, you who are blessed by the Lord. Why are you standing outside when I have prepared the house and a place for the camels?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man came to the house and unloaded the camels. Laban gave him straw and feed for the camels and water to wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Food was set before him to eat, but he said, “I will not eat until I have delivered my message.”
Laban said, “Tell us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “I am Abraham’s servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has blessed my master greatly. He has become great. The Lord has given him flocks and herds, silver and gold, male servants and female servants, camels and donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah, my master’s wife, bore a son for my master when she was old. My master has given him everything that he owns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My master made me take an oath. He said, ‘You must not acquire a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I am living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, you shall go to my father’s house and to my relatives and acquire a wife for my son.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I asked my master, ‘What if the woman will not follow me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to me, ‘The Lord, in whose presence I walk, will send his angel with you and give your journey success, and you will acquire a wife for my son from my relatives and from my father’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you will be released from my oath, if, when you have come to my relatives, they do not give her to you—then you will be released from my oath.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today I came to the spring and said, ‘O Lord, the God of my master Abraham, if you now will bless my journey with success,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (here I am, standing by this spring of water) let this be the test: If the virgin who comes out to draw water (the one to whom I say, “Please give me a little water to drink from your water jar”)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: tells me, “Drink, and I will also draw water for your camels,” she will be the woman whom the Lord has chosen for my master’s son.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before I had finished saying this to myself, out came Rebekah with her water jar on her shoulder. She went down to the spring and drew water. I said to her, ‘Please give me a drink.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She hurried and lowered her water jar from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink, and I will also give your camels a drink.’ So I drank, and she also gave the camels a drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ She said, ‘The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor’s son, whom Milcah bore for him.’ I put the ring on her nose and the bracelets on her wrists.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I bowed my head and worshipped the Lord and blessed the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me in the right way to find the daughter of my master’s brother as a wife for his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now if you will show mercy and faithfulness to my master here, tell me. If not, tell me, so that I may know whether to turn to the right or to the left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Laban and Bethuel answered, “This matter has been determined by the Lord. We cannot say anything to you either bad or good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, Rebekah is right here in front of you. Take her and go, and let her become the wife of your master’s son, as the Lord has spoken.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So, when Abraham’s servant heard their words, he bowed down to the ground before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant brought out silver and gold jewelry and clothing and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave valuable gifts to her brother and her mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He and the men who were with him ate and drank, and they spent the night there. They got up in the morning, and he said, “Send me on my way to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her brother and her mother said, “Let the young lady stay with us a few days, at least ten. After that she can go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Do not hold me back, since the Lord has granted my journey success. Send me on my way so that I can go to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “We will call the young lady and ask her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They called Rebekah and asked her, “Do you want to go with this man?”
She said, “I do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent all of them on their way—their sister Rebekah with her nurse, Abraham’s servant, and his men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They blessed Rebekah and said to her, “May you, our sister, be the mother of thousands of ten thousands, and let your offspring take possession of the gates of those who hate them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah set out with her female attendants. They rode on the camels and followed the man. Abraham’s servant took Rebekah and set out on his journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac had come from the direction of Be’er Lahai Roi, for he was living in the Negev.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the evening Isaac had gone out into the field to meditate. He looked up and saw that there were camels coming.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah also looked up, and when she saw Isaac, she jumped down from the camel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She said to the servant, “Who is that man who is walking through the field to meet us?”
The servant said, “It is my master.”
She took her veil and covered herself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant told Isaac everything that he had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac brought Rebekah into his mother Sarah’s tent, and he took her as his wife. He loved her, and Isaac stopped mourning his mother’s death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham had taken another wife. Her name was Keturah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She bore Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jokshan became the father of Sheba and Dedan. The descendants of Dedan were the Ashshurites, Letushites, and Leummites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Elda’ah. All these were the descendants of Keturah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham left all that he had to Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To the sons of his concubines Abraham gave gifts, and during his lifetime he sent them away from Isaac his son to the territory that lay to the east.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total days and years of Abraham’s life were one hundred seventy-five years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham breathed his last and died at a good old age, an old man who lived a full life, and he was gathered to his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the Cave of Machpelah in the field of Ephron, the son of Zohar the Hittite, which is near Mamre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was the field that Abraham had purchased from the descendants of Heth. Abraham was buried there with Sarah, his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the death of Abraham, God blessed Isaac, his son. Isaac lived near Be’er Lahai Roi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now this is the account about the development of the family line of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s maid, had borne to Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The following are the names of the sons of Ishmael and the tribes that came from them, arranged in the order of their birth:
The firstborn of Ishmael was Nebaioth. Then came Kedar, Adbe’el, Mibsam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Ishmael, arranged by their settlements and by their camps. They were twelve chiefs, each with his own tribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total years of the life of Ishmael were one hundred thirty-seven years. When he breathed his last and died, he was gathered to his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His people lived between Havilah and Shur, east of Egypt, as you go toward Ashshur. He lived in hostility toward all his relatives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account about the development of the family of Isaac, Abraham’s son.
Abraham became the father of Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac was forty years old when he took Rebekah, who was the daughter of Bethuel, an Aramean from Paddan Aram, and the sister of Laban the Aramean, to be his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac prayed to the Lord for his wife, because she was barren. The Lord answered his prayer, and Rebekah his wife conceived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The children fought with each other inside her. She said, “What is this? Why is this happening to me?” She went to inquire of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to her:
Two nations are in your womb.
Two peoples will be separated from your body.
The one people will be stronger than the other people.
The elder will serve the younger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was time for her to give birth, it was true: There were twins in her womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The first came out red all over, like a hairy garment. They named him Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that, his brother came out, with his hand grabbing Esau’s heel. So he was named Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when she gave birth to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The boys grew up. Esau was a skillful hunter, an outdoorsman. Jacob was a quiet man, who stayed home among the tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Isaac loved Esau more, because he ate Esau’s wild game. Rebekah loved Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once Jacob was cooking stew, and Esau came in from the field, and he was starving.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said to Jacob, “Come on, let me eat some of that red stew, that red stew there, because I am starving.” (That is why Esau was also called Edom.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said, “First, sell me your right as the firstborn.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said, “Look, I am about to die. What good is the birthright to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jacob said, “Swear to me first.”
So he swore to him and sold his birthright to Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob gave Esau bread and a stew made of lentils. Esau ate and drank, got up, and went on his way. So Esau treated his birthright as if it was worthless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a famine in the land, besides the first famine that had occurred during the days of Abraham. Isaac went to Abimelek king of the Philistines at Gerar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to him and said, “Do not go down into Egypt. Live in the land where I tell you to live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Live in this land, and I will be with you and will bless you. For to you and to your descendants I will give all these lands, and I will establish the oath that I swore to Abraham your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will multiply your descendants like the stars of the sky and will give all these lands to your descendants. In your seed all the nations of the earth will be blessed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because Abraham obeyed my voice and kept my requirements, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac lived in Gerar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the men of that place asked him about his wife, he said, “She is my sister.” He was afraid to say, “She is my wife,” because he thought, “The men of this place might kill me for Rebekah, since she is beautiful.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had been there a long time, Abimelek king of the Philistines happened to look out a window, and there was Isaac caressing Rebekah, his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abimelek called Isaac and said, “It is obvious that she is your wife. So why did you say, ‘She is my sister’?”
Isaac said to him, “Because I thought, ‘If I do not, I will die because of her.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek said, “What is this you have done to us? One of the people might easily have slept with your wife, and you would have brought guilt on us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek gave this command to all the people: “Whoever touches this man or his wife shall surely be put to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac planted grain in that land, and in the same year he reaped one hundred times as much as he had sown, because the Lord blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man kept growing wealthier and wealthier until he became very great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He possessed flocks and herds and a large household, so the Philistines were envious of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Philistines had blocked all the wells that his father’s servants had dug in the days of Abraham his father, and they had filled them with earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelek said to Isaac, “Move away from us, for you are much more powerful than we are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac departed from there, camped in the valley of Gerar, and lived there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac dug again the wells that had been dug in the days of Abraham his father, because the Philistines had blocked them after the death of Abraham. He gave them the same names that his father had given them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac’s servants dug in the valley along the stream bed and found a well there that provided a steady flow of water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the herdsmen of Gerar started a dispute with Isaac’s herdsmen. They said, “The water belongs to us.” He named the well Esek, because they argued with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They dug another well, but they started a dispute over that one also. He named it Sitnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He left that place and dug another well. They did not start a dispute over that one, so he called it Rehoboth. He said, “Now the Lord has made room for us, and we will be fruitful in the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He traveled from there to Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to him the same night and said, “I am the God of Abraham your father. Do not be afraid, for I am with you, and I will bless you and multiply your descendants for the sake of my servant Abraham.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built an altar there and proclaimed the name of the Lord. He pitched his tent there. Isaac’s servants dug a well there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelek came from Gerar, with Ahuzzath his advisor and Phicol the commander of his army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac said to them, “Why have you come to me, since you hate me and have sent me away from you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “We saw clearly that the Lord was with you. So we said, ‘Let there now be an oath between us, yes, between us and you. Let us make a treaty with you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that you will do us no harm, since we have not touched you, and since we have done nothing but good for you, and we have sent you away in peace.’ Now you are blessed by the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made a feast for them, and they ate and drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They got up the next morning and exchanged their oaths. Isaac sent them on their way, and they departed from him peacefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It so happened that on the same day Isaac’s servants came and told him about a well that they had dug. They said to him, “We have found water.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called it Shibah. Therefore the name of the city is Beersheba to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Esau was forty years old, he took two wives: Judith, the daughter of Be’eri the Hittite, and Basemath, the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were a source of bitterness for Isaac and Rebekah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Isaac was old and his eyes were so dim that he could hardly see, he called Esau his older son and said to him, “My son?”
He said to him, “I am here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac said, “Look, I am very old, and I do not know when I am going to die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So please take your gear, your quiver, and your bow, and go out to the open country, and get some wild game for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make me tasty food, the kind I love, and bring it to me, so that I may eat and I may bless you with all my soul before I die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah had been listening when Isaac spoke to Esau his son. After Esau went to the open country to hunt for game and to bring it back,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah spoke to Jacob her son and said, “Listen, I heard your father speak to Esau your brother and tell him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Bring me some wild game and make tasty food for me, that I may eat and give you a blessing from the Lord before my death.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, my son, obey my voice and do what I am commanding you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go now to the flock, and get me two of the best young goats. I will make them into tasty food for your father, the kind he loves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will bring it to your father, so that he can eat it and bless you before his death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to his mother Rebekah, “But Esau my brother is a hairy man, and my skin is smooth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What if my father touches me? I will be exposed to him as a deceiver, and I will bring a curse on myself and not a blessing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His mother said to him, “Let your curse be on me, my son. Just obey my voice, and go get them for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went and got them and brought them to his mother. His mother made tasty food, the kind his father loved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah took the good clothing of Esau, her older son, which was with her in the house, and put it on Jacob, her younger son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She put the skins of the young goats on his hands and forearms and on the smooth part of his neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She put the tasty food and the bread that she had prepared into the hand of her son Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He came to his father and said, “My father?”
He said, “I am here. Who are you, my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau your firstborn. I have done what you asked me to do. Please get up, and sit here and eat some of my wild game, so that you may bless me with all your soul.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isaac said to his son, “How is it that you have found it so quickly, my son?”
He said, “Because the Lord your God gave me success.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac said to Jacob, “Please come near, so that I may feel you, my son, whether you are really my son Esau or not.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob went close to Isaac his father, who felt him and said, “The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did not recognize him, because his hands were hairy, like his brother Esau’s hands. That was why he blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But he asked again, “Are you really my son Esau?”
He said, “I am.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “Bring it to me, and I will eat some of my son’s wild game, so that I may bless you.”
Jacob brought it to him, and he ate. He brought him wine, and he drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His father Isaac said to him, “Come near now, and kiss me, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He came near and kissed him. He smelled his clothing, so he blessed him and said:
Yes, the smell of my son is the smell of the open field
that the Lord has blessed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May God give you the dew from the sky,
the richness of the earth,
and plenty of grain and new wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let peoples serve you,
and nations bow down to you.
Be lord over your brothers.
Let your mother’s sons bow down to you.
Cursed be everyone who curses you.
Blessed be everyone who blesses you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had just gone out from the presence of Isaac his father, Esau his brother came in from his hunting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also prepared tasty food and brought it to his father. He said to his father, “Let my father get up and eat his son’s wild game, so that you may bless me with all your soul.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isaac his father said to him, “Who are you?”
He said, “I am your son, your firstborn, Esau.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac trembled violently and said, “Then who was it that hunted wild game and brought it to me? I ate all of it before you came, and I have blessed him. And, yes, he will be blessed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Esau heard the words of his father, he let out a very loud and bitter cry and said to his father, “Bless me—me too, my father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Your brother came deceitfully and has taken away your blessing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said, “Isn’t he rightly named Jacob? For he has tripped me up these two times. He took away my birthright. And look, now he has taken away my blessing.” He also asked, “Haven’t you reserved a blessing for me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac answered Esau, “You see, I have made him your lord, and I have given all his brothers to him as servants. I have sustained him with grain and new wine. So what can I do for you, my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said to his father, “Have you only one blessing, my father? Bless me—me too, my father.” And Esau wept loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isaac his father answered him,
Know this:
Your dwelling will be away from the richness of the earth
and away from the dew from the sky above.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By your sword you will live, but you will serve your brother.
Then when you break loose, you will shake his yoke off your neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing with which his father had blessed him. Esau said in his heart, “The days of mourning for my father are at hand. Then I will kill my brother Jacob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of Esau, her older son, were told to Rebekah. She sent and called Jacob, her younger son, and said to him, “Listen, your brother Esau is consoling himself in regard to you by planning to kill you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, therefore, my son, obey my voice. Get up. Flee to Laban, my brother, in Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay with him a few days, until your brother’s fury turns away,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: until your brother’s anger turns away from you, and he forgets what you have done to him. Then I will send for you and get you from there. Why should I be deprived of both of you in one day?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am tired of my life because of the daughters of Heth. If Jacob takes a wife from the daughters of Heth, these daughters of the land, what good will my life do me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac called Jacob, blessed him, and commanded him, “You shall not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get up. Go to Paddan Aram, to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father. Take a wife from there from the daughters of Laban, your mother’s brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God Almighty bless you, and make you fruitful, and multiply you, so that you may become a community of peoples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May he give you and your descendants along with you the blessing he gave to Abraham, so that you may inherit the land where you have been living as an alien, the land God gave to Abraham.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac sent Jacob away. He went to Paddan Aram to Laban, the son of Bethuel the Aramean. Laban was the brother of Rebekah, who was the mother of Jacob and Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau observed that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him away to Paddan Aram to take a wife from there, and that as he blessed him, he had commanded him, “You shall not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he saw that Jacob had obeyed his father and his mother and had gone to Paddan Aram,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau realized that the daughters of Canaan did not please Isaac, his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau went to Ishmael, and he took Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham’s son, the sister of Nebaioth, to be his wife, in addition to the wives that he already had.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob set out from Beersheba and traveled toward Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He came to a certain place and decided to spend the night there, because the sun had set. He took one of the stones from that place, put it under his head, and lay down to sleep in that place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had a dream in which he saw a stairway set up on the earth with its top reaching to heaven. There were angels of God ascending and descending on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There at the top stood the Lord, who said, “I am the Lord, the God of your father Abraham and the God of Isaac. The land on which you are lying, I give to you and to your descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread abroad to the west, and to the east, and to the north, and to the south. In you and in your seed all the families of the earth will be blessed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go, and I will bring you back again into this land. Indeed, I will not leave you until I have done what I have promised to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob woke up from his sleep, and he said, “Certainly the Lord is in this place, and I was not aware of it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was afraid and he said, “How awe- inspiring is this place! This is nothing other than the house of God, and this is the gate to heaven.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob got up early in the morning. He took the stone that he had put under his head and set it up as a sacred memorial stone and poured oil on top of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He named that place Bethel. (Before this, the name of the city had been Luz.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob took a vow, “If God will be with me to keep me safe on this journey I am making, and if he gives me food to eat and clothing to put on,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I come back to my father’s house in safety, the Lord will be my God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and this stone that I have set up as a memorial stone will be God’s house, and I will certainly give you a tenth of everything that you give me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob continued on his journey and came to the land of the people of the east.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He looked around and noticed a well in the field, and he saw three flocks of sheep lying there beside it. (That well was used to water the flocks. There was a large stone over the mouth of the well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the flocks would gather there. Then the shepherds would roll the stone away from the mouth of the well and water the sheep. Then they would put the stone back in its place over the mouth of the well.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jacob said to the men waiting there, “My brothers, where are you from?”
They said, “We are from Haran.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said to them, “Do you know Laban, the grandson of Nahor?”
They said, “We know him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said to them, “Is he doing well?”
They said, “He is. Look, there is his daughter Rachel, coming with the sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Look, it is still the middle of the day. It is not time to gather the livestock together. Water the sheep and go pasture them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “We cannot, until all the flocks are gathered together, and they roll the stone from the mouth of the well. Then we water the sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still speaking with them, Rachel arrived with her father’s sheep because she took care of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob saw Rachel the daughter of Laban, his mother’s brother, and the sheep of Laban, his mother’s brother, Jacob went up, rolled the stone away from the mouth of the well, and watered the flock of Laban, his mother’s brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob kissed Rachel and wept loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob told Rachel that he was her father’s relative and that he was Rebekah’s son. She ran and told her father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Laban heard the news about Jacob, his sister’s son, he ran to meet Jacob. He embraced him and kissed him and brought him to his house. Jacob repeated all these things to Laban.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Laban said to him, “Certainly you are my own flesh and blood.”
Jacob lived with him for a month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Laban said to Jacob, “Because you are my relative, is that any reason you should serve me for nothing? Tell me, what shall your wages be?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban had two daughters. The name of the older one was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah had attractive eyes, but Rachel had a beautiful face and figure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob loved Rachel. He said, “I will serve you seven years for Rachel, your younger daughter.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said, “It is better for me to give her to you than to give her to another man. Stay with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob served seven years for Rachel. They seemed to him like a few days, because of the love he had for her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to Laban, “Give me my wife, for my time of service is finished, so that I may go to her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban gathered together all the local people and made a feast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When evening had arrived, he took Leah his daughter and brought her to Jacob, and Jacob went to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Laban gave his maid Zilpah to his daughter Leah as her maid.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When morning came, Jacob realized it was Leah. So Jacob said to Laban, “What is this you have done to me? Didn’t I serve you for Rachel? Why have you deceived me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said, “That is not the way we do it here. We do not give the younger before the firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fulfill the marriage week for this one, and we will give you the other one too—for seven more years of service.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that is what Jacob did. When he fulfilled the marriage week, Laban gave him Rachel his daughter as his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Laban gave his maid Bilhah to his daughter Rachel to be her maid.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob also went to Rachel, and he loved Rachel more than Leah. He served Laban seven more years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord saw that Leah was not loved, and he allowed her to conceive, but Rachel had no children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son, and she named him Reuben, because she had said, “The Lord has looked at my misery. So now my husband will love me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived again and gave birth to a son and said, “Because the Lord has heard that I am hated, he has given me this son also.” So she named him Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived again and gave birth to a son. She said, “Now this time my husband will be attached to me, because I have given birth to three sons for him.” That is why he was named Levi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived again and gave birth to a son. She said, “This time I will praise the Lord.” So she named him Judah. Then she stopped having children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rachel saw that she was bearing no children for Jacob, Rachel was jealous of her sister. She said to Jacob, “Give me children, or else I will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob’s anger burned against Rachel, and he said, “Am I in the place of God, who has withheld from you fruit from your womb?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “Here is my maid Bilhah. Go to her, so that she may bear a child for me, and my family will be built up through her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she gave her servant girl Bilhah to Jacob as a wife, and he went to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bilhah conceived and gave birth to a son for Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rachel said, “God has judged in my favor. He has heard my voice and has given me a son.” Therefore she named him Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bilhah, Rachel’s servant girl, conceived again and bore Jacob a second son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rachel said, “I have had a desperate struggle with my sister, and I have won.” So she named him Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Leah saw that she was no longer bearing sons, she took her servant girl Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zilpah, Leah’s servant girl, bore Jacob a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah said, “How fortunate!” So she named him Gad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zilpah, Leah’s servant girl, bore a second son for Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah said, “I am blessed, for women will call me blessed.” She named him Asher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the time of the wheat harvest Reuben went out and found mandrakes in the field and brought them to his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, “Please give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She said to her, “Isn’t it bad enough that you have taken away my husband? Do you want to take away my son’s mandrakes as well?”
Rachel said, “He will sleep with you tonight for your son’s mandrakes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Jacob came in from the field in the evening, Leah went out to meet him and said, “You must come to me, because I have hired you with my son’s mandrakes.”
So he slept with her that night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God listened to Leah, and she conceived and bore Jacob a fifth son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah said, “God has given me the wages I deserve, because I gave my servant girl to my husband.” So she named him Issachar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah conceived again and bore a sixth son to Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah said, “God has given me a great reward. Now my husband will treat me with honor, because I have borne six sons for him.” So she named him Zebulun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward, she gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God remembered Rachel, and God listened to her and opened her womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived, bore a son, and said, “God has taken away my disgrace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She named him Joseph and said, “May the Lord add another son to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Send me away, that I may go home to my own place in my own country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give me my wives and my children for whom I have served you, and let me go, because you know how much I have served you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said to him, “If now I have found favor in your eyes, stay here, for I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me because of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said, “Set your wages for me, and I will pay them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to him, “You know how well I have served you, and how your livestock have fared under my care.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For before I came, you had very little, and it has been multiplied many times over. The Lord has blessed you wherever I set foot. Now isn’t it time for me to provide for my own household as well?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Laban asked, “What shall I give you?”
Jacob said, “You do not have to give me anything. But if you will do this thing for me, I will continue to take your flock to pasture and watch over it:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will pass through all your flocks today and take all the speckled and spotted sheep, every dark brown sheep among the lambs, and the spotted and speckled goats. These will be my wages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how I will be able to prove my honesty whenever you demand an accounting of my wages: Any goats that are not spotted or speckled, and any lambs that are not dark brown that are found with me will be treated as stolen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said, “Very well. We will do what you have said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But that day Laban removed all the male goats that were streaked and spotted, and all the female goats that were speckled and spotted, every one that had any white on it, and all the dark brown sheep, and handed them over to his sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he separated himself from Jacob by a three days’ journey, and Jacob pastured the rest of Laban’s flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob took fresh branches from poplar, almond, and plane trees. He peeled stripes on them so that the white inside the branches was visible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put the branches that he had peeled into the gutters of the watering troughs where the flocks came to drink, so the flocks would see them. They conceived when they came to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The flocks conceived in front of the branches, and the flocks produced streaked, speckled, and spotted animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob separated the lambs, and he made the flocks face toward the streaked animals and all the black animals in the flock of Laban, and he kept his own herds separate and did not put them into Laban’s flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And whenever the stronger animals in the flock were in heat, Jacob laid the branches in the gutters where the flocks could see them, so that they would conceive while looking at the branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the weak animals in the flock were in heat, he did not put the branches in. So the weaker animals were Laban’s, and the stronger were Jacob’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man became much wealthier and had large flocks, female servants and male servants, and camels and donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob heard that Laban’s sons were saying, “Jacob has taken everything from our father. He has acquired all his wealth from things that belonged to our father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the look on Laban’s face Jacob realized that his attitude toward him was not what it had been before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Jacob, “Return to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob sent for Rachel and Leah and told them to come to the field where his flock was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “I see the look on your father’s face, and it is not favorable toward me as it was before, but the God of my father has been with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that I have served your father with all of my strength.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your father has cheated me by changing my wages ten times, but God did not allow him to hurt me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he said, ‘The speckled animals will be your wages,’ then all the flock gave birth to speckled young. If he said, ‘The streaked animals will be your wages,’ then all the flock gave birth to streaked young.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way God has taken away your father’s livestock and given them to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once during mating season, in a dream I watched and saw male goats that were streaked, speckled, and spotted mating with the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Angel of God called out to me in the dream, ‘Jacob,’ and I answered, ‘I am here.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, ‘Look! All the male goats mating with the flock are streaked, speckled, and spotted, because I have seen everything that Laban has been doing to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed a memorial stone, and where you made a vow to me. Now get going, get out of this land, and return to the land where you were born.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rachel and Leah answered him, “Do we still have any share of the inheritance in our father’s house?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t he treating us like foreigners? First he sold us. Now he has used up almost all the money he received for us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the riches that God has taken away from our father belong to us and our children. Now do whatever God has told you to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob got ready to go. He placed his sons and his wives on camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took with him all his livestock and all his possessions that he had accumulated, including the livestock that he had acquired in Paddan Aram. He set out to go to Isaac his father in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now when Laban had gone off to shear his sheep, Rachel stole her father’s household gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob deceived Laban the Aramean by not telling him that he was running away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he fled with all that he had. He set out, crossed over the Euphrates River, and headed toward the hill country of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day Laban was told that Jacob had fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took his relatives with him and pursued him for seven days. He overtook him in the hill country of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream during the night and said to him, “Be careful that you do not say anything to Jacob either good or bad.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban caught up with Jacob. Jacob had pitched his tent in the hill country, and Laban along with his relatives also set up camp in the hill country of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said to Jacob, “What have you done? Why have you deceived me and carried away my daughters like prisoners of war?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you flee secretly and steal from me? Why didn’t you tell me, so that I could have sent you away with a celebration and with songs, with drums and with lyres?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why didn’t you allow me to kiss my sons and my daughters? By doing this you have acted foolishly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have it in my power to hurt you, but the God of your father spoke to me last night and said, ‘Be careful that you do not say anything to Jacob either good or bad.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But even if you were so eager to leave because of your strong desire to return to your father’s house, why have you stolen my gods?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob answered Laban, “I was afraid, because I thought that you might take your daughters away from me by force.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But anyone with whom you find your gods shall not live. In the presence of our relatives, identify anything I have that belongs to you, and take it.” (Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen the household gods.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Laban went into Jacob’s tent, into Leah’s tent, and into the tent of the two female servants, but he did not find the gods. After he had left Leah’s tent, he entered Rachel’s tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rachel had taken the household gods and put them into her camel’s saddle, and she was sitting on them. Laban felt all around the tent, but he did not find them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rachel said to her father, “Do not be angry, my lord, because I cannot stand up in your presence. I’m having my period.” He searched, but he did not find the gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob became angry and argued with Laban. Jacob responded to Laban, “What is my crime? What is my sin that set you off in hot pursuit after me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now that you have rummaged through all my belongings, what have you found there that came from your house? Set it out here in front of my relatives and your relatives, so that they can settle the case between the two of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These twenty years that I have been with you, your ewes and your female goats have not miscarried their young, and I have not eaten rams from your flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I did not bring to you those that were torn up by wild animals. I bore the loss myself. You made me pay for all the losses, whether they were stolen by day or stolen by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was the one out there, consumed by the scorching heat of the day and by the frost at night, and sleep fled from my eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These twenty years I put up with this in your house: I served you fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for a share of your flock, and you have changed my wages ten times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Unless the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the God revered by Isaac, had been with me, you certainly would have now sent me away empty-handed. But God saw the oppression I suffered and the labor of my hands, and he rebuked you last night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban answered Jacob, “These daughters are my daughters. These children are my children. These flocks are my flocks, and all that you see is mine, but what can I do today about these daughters of mine or about the children to whom they have given birth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now come, let us make a covenant, you and I, and let it stand as a witness between me and you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a memorial stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to his relatives, “Gather stones.” They collected stones and piled them up. They ate there beside the pile of stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban called it Jegar Sahadutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said, “This pile of stones is a witness between me and you this day.” So it was named Galeed
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Mizpah, for he also said, “May the Lord watch between me and you, when we are absent one from another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you mistreat my daughters, or if you take any wives in addition to my daughters, even if no one else sees it, understand that God is a witness between me and you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said to Jacob, “See this pile of stones and see the memorial stone that I have set between me and you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May this pile be a witness, and may the memorial stone be a witness that I will not cross over beyond this pile to you, and that you will not cross over beyond this pile and this memorial stone to harm me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May the God of Abraham and the God of Nahor, the God of their father, judge between us.”
Then Jacob swore by the God revered by his father Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob offered a sacrifice there in the hill country and invited his relatives to eat bread with him. They ate bread and stayed all night in the hill country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning Laban got up, kissed his sons and his daughters, and blessed them. Laban departed and returned to his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob went on his way, and the angels of God met him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he saw them, Jacob said, “This is God’s army.” He named that place Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob sent messengers ahead of him to Esau, his brother, to the land of Seir, the region of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gave them a command. “Tell my lord, Esau, ‘This is what your servant Jacob says: I have lived as an alien with Laban until very recently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have cattle, donkeys, flocks, male servants, and female servants. I have sent this message to inform my lord, so that I may find favor in your sight.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messengers returned to Jacob and reported, “We came to your brother Esau. Now he is coming to meet you, and he has four hundred men with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob was terrified and very distressed. He divided the people who were with him, as well as the flocks, and the herds, and the camels, into two camps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “If Esau comes to one camp and strikes it, then the other camp will escape.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said, “God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, the Lord, who said to me, ‘Return to your country and to your relatives, and I will do good for you,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am not worthy of even a bit of all the mercy and all the faithfulness that you have shown to your servant, for I crossed over this Jordan with just my staff, and now I have grown into two camps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please deliver me from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau, for I am afraid that he will come and strike me and the mothers, as well as the children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You said, ‘I will surely do good for you and make your descendants like the grains of sand of the sea, which cannot be counted because there are so many.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob spent that night there and selected a gift for Esau his brother from the possessions he had with him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: thirty milk camels and their colts, forty cows and ten bulls, and twenty female donkeys with ten foals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He handed them over to his servants, each herd by itself, and said to his servants, “Cross over in front of me, and keep some space between each herd and the next one.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He commanded the one in front, “When Esau my brother meets you and asks, ‘Whose people are you? Where are you going? Whose herds are these in front of you?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then you shall say, ‘They belong to your servant Jacob. It is a gift sent to you, my lord Esau. Look, he is right behind us.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He commanded the second group, and the third, and all those who followed the herds, “This is how you shall speak to Esau when you meet him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall say, ‘What’s more, look, your servant Jacob is right behind us.’” Jacob said, “I will win his favor with the gift that I have sent ahead of me, and after that I will see his face, and perhaps he will accept me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the gift was sent over ahead of him, but he himself spent that night in the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He got up that night and took his two wives, his two maids, and his eleven sons, and crossed over the ford of the Jabbok.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took them and sent them across the stream, and he also sent his possessions across.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob was left alone, and he wrestled with a man there until daybreak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the man saw that he could not defeat him, he touched the socket of his thigh, and the socket of Jacob’s thigh was dislocated as he wrestled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The man said, “Let me go. It’s daybreak.”
Jacob said, “I will not let you go unless you bless me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he said to him, “What is your name?”
He said, “Jacob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said, “Your name will no longer be Jacob, but Israel, because you have fought with God and with men, and you have won.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jacob asked him, “Please tell me your name.”
He said, “Why do you ask what my name is?” Then he blessed him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob named the place Peniel, because he said, “I have seen God face-to-face, and my life has been spared.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sun rose as he crossed over at Peniel, and he was limping because of his thigh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For that reason, to this day the people of Israel do not eat the tendon of the hip that is on the socket of the thigh, because God touched the socket of Jacob’s thigh on the tendon of the hip.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob looked up, and there was Esau coming with four hundred men. Jacob divided the children into groups with Leah and Rachel and with the two maids.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put the maids and their children in front, Leah and her children next, and Rachel and Joseph at the end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He himself crossed over the stream ahead of the others and bowed to the ground seven times as he approached his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau ran to meet him, embraced him, hugged him around the neck, and kissed him. They both wept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Esau looked up and saw the women and children and asked, “Who are these people with you?”
Jacob said, “The children whom God has graciously given your servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the maids came forward with their children, and they bowed low.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah and her children also came forward and bowed low. After them, Joseph came forward with Rachel, and they bowed low.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Esau said, “What did you mean by this whole camp that I met?”
Jacob said, “To gain favor in the sight of my lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said, “I have enough, my brother. Keep what is yours.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said, “No, if I have now found favor in your sight, then please accept the gift from my hand, because when I saw your face, it was like seeing the face of God, now that you have accepted me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please accept the gift that I brought to you, because God has dealt graciously with me, and because I have everything I need.” He urged him, and he accepted it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said, “Let us get going on our journey, and I will lead the way for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to him, “My lord knows that the children are still young, and that my flocks and herds are nursing their young, and if the herdsmen drive them too hard for even one day, all the flocks will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please let my lord go ahead of his servant, and I will follow slowly, at the right pace for the livestock and the right pace for the children, until I come to my lord in Seir.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Esau said, “Please let me leave some of my people with you.”
But he said, “Why? Just let me find favor in the sight of my lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau set out that day on his way back to Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob traveled to Succoth, built a house for himself, and made shelters for his livestock. That is why that place is called Succoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator
