verses.text: When he returned from Paddan Aram, Jacob came in peace to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, and he camped in front of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He bought the piece of land where he pitched his tent from the descendants of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for one hundred pieces of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He erected an altar there and called it El Elohe Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dinah, Jacob’s daughter by Leah, went out to see the young women of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shechem, the son of Hamor the Hivite, the chief of that part of the land, saw her and took her, lay down with her, and humiliated her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had a strong desire for Dinah, the daughter of Jacob, and he was in love with the young woman and spoke tenderly to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shechem spoke to his father, Hamor, saying, “Get me this young woman as a wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob heard that Shechem had defiled his daughter Dinah, his sons were out in the field with his livestock, so Jacob kept quiet about it until they came back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hamor the father of Shechem came to talk with Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Jacob came in from the field when they heard about it. The men were shocked by the outrage, and they were very angry, because he had disgraced Israel by lying down with Jacob’s daughter, a thing that should not be done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hamor spoke with them. He said, “My son Shechem has a deep longing for your daughter. Please give her to him as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Intermarry with us. Give your daughters to us, and take our daughters for yourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may live among us, and the land will be open to you. Live in it, conduct trade, and acquire property in it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shechem said to her father and to her brothers, “Let me find favor in your eyes, and whatever you ask from me I will give.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No matter how great a bride price and gift you demand, I will give it. Just give me the young woman as a wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Jacob answered Shechem and his father Hamor deceitfully, because Shechem had defiled their sister Dinah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to them, “We cannot do this—giving our sister to a man who is uncircumcised. That would be a disgrace to us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only on this condition will we consent to your offer: If all your males become circumcised as we are,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then we will give our daughters to you, and we will take your daughters for ourselves, and we will live with you, and we will become one people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you do not accept our terms and undergo circumcision, then we will take our sister, and we will be gone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their offer pleased Hamor and Hamor’s son Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man did not delay acting on it, because he was delighted with Jacob’s daughter, and he was the most important of all the household of his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hamor and his son Shechem came to the gate of their city and discussed this with the men of their city. They said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “These men want peace with us. So let them live in the land and trade in it. Look, the land is large enough for them. Let us take their daughters as wives for ourselves, and let us give them our daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only on this condition will the men agree to live with us and to become one people with us: if every male among us is circumcised, as they are circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Won’t all their livestock, all their possessions, and all their animals become ours? So let’s accept their offer, so that they will settle among us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone who assembled at the gate of his city listened to Hamor and to Shechem his son. So all the males who assembled at the gate of the city were circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then on the third day, when they were still sore, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, each took his sword, attacked the unsuspecting city, and killed all the males.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They killed Hamor and Shechem, his son, with the edge of the sword. They took Dinah out of Shechem’s house and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob’s sons then came to the dead bodies and looted the city, because their sister had been defiled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took their flocks, their herds, their donkeys, everything that was in the city, everything that was in the countryside,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and all their wealth. They took all their little ones and their wives as captives. They looted everything that was in the houses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have ruined me. You have made me stink to the inhabitants of the land, among the Canaanites and the Perizzites. I am few in number. They will gather themselves together against me and attack me, and I will be destroyed, I and my household.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they said, “Should he have treated our sister like a prostitute?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to Jacob, “Get up and go to Bethel, and live there. Make an altar there for God, who appeared to you when you fled from the presence of Esau your brother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him, “Throw away the foreign gods that are among you, purify yourselves, and change your clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let’s get up and go to Bethel. I will make an altar there for God, who answered me in the day when I was in trouble and who has been with me wherever I have traveled.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They gave Jacob all the foreign gods that were in their possession and the rings that were in their ears, and Jacob hid them under the terebinth tree that was near Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set out, and terror from God fell on the cities that were around them, so they did not pursue Jacob’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob came to Luz (that is, Bethel), which is in the land of Canaan, he and all the people who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built an altar there and named the place El Beth El, because God had been revealed to him there, when he fled from the presence of his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Deborah, who was Rebekah’s nurse, died, and she was buried under the oak below Bethel. So the place was named Allon Bacuth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God appeared to Jacob again after he had come from Paddan Aram, and he blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to him, “Your name is Jacob, but your name will not be Jacob anymore. Your name will be Israel.” So he named him Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to him, “I am God Almighty. Be fruitful and multiply. A nation and a community of nations will descend from you, and kings will come from your body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land that I gave to Abraham and Isaac, I will give also to you, and I will give the land to your descendants after you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God left him in the place where he had spoken with him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Jacob set up a memorial in the place where God had spoken with him. It was a memorial stone. He poured out a drink offering on it and poured oil on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob named the place where God spoke with him Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they traveled from Bethel. As they were coming close to Ephrath, Rachel went into labor. She was experiencing hard labor,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and when she was in hard labor, the midwife said to her, “Don’t be afraid, for now you will have another son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then as her life was slipping away (for she was dying), she named her son Benoni, but his father named him Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob set up a memorial stone on her grave. It is the marker for Rachel’s tomb to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel traveled on and pitched his tent beyond Migdal Eder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While Israel lived in that region, Reuben went and lay down with Bilhah, his father’s concubine, and Israel heard about it.
Jacob had twelve sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Leah were Reuben (Jacob’s firstborn), Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Bilhah (Rachel’s maid) were Dan and Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Zilpah (Leah’s maid) were Gad and Asher.
These are the sons of Jacob who were born to him in Paddan Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob came to his father Isaac at Mamre near Kiriath Arba (which is Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had resided as aliens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The days of Isaac’s life were one hundred eighty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac breathed his last and died. He was gathered to his people. He had lived a long, full life. Esau and Jacob, his sons, buried him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now this is the account about the descendants of Esau (that is, Edom):
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau took Canaanite women as his wives. They were Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also married Basemath, Ishmael’s daughter, the sister of Nebaioth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adah gave birth to Eliphaz for Esau.
Basemath gave birth to Reuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oholibamah gave birth to Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
These are the sons of Esau, who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, and all the members of his household, along with his livestock, all his animals, and all the possessions that he had accumulated in the land of Canaan, and he went into another land, away from his brother Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their herds were too large for them to stay together, and the land where they had settled could not support both of them because of their livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau lived in the hill country of Seir. (Esau is another name for Edom.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account about the descendants of Esau, who was the founding father of Edom in the hill country of Seir:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the names of Esau’s sons: Eliphaz the son of Esau’s wife Adah, and Reuel the son of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Timna was the concubine of Esau’s son Eliphaz, and she gave birth to Amalek for Eliphaz. These are the grandsons of Esau’s wife Adah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the grandsons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following were the sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah, the granddaughter of Zibeon. She gave birth to Jeush, Jalam, and Korah for Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The following are the chiefs of the clans of the descendants of Esau:
From the descendants of Eliphaz the firstborn of Esau they were Chief Teman, Chief Omar, Chief Zepho, Chief Kenaz,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chief Korah, Chief Gatam, and Chief Amalek. These are the chiefs who descended from Eliphaz in the land of Edom. These are the descendants of Adah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the descendants of Esau’s son Reuel: Chief Nahath, Chief Zerah, Chief Shammah, and Chief Mizzah. These are the chiefs who descended from Reuel in the land of Edom. These are the descendants of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the descendants of Esau’s wife Oholibamah: Chief Jeush, Chief Jalam, and Chief Korah. These are the chiefs who came from Esau’s wife Oholibamah daughter of Anah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the descendants of Esau (that is, Edom), and these are their chiefs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the sons of Seir the Horite, who lived in the land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These are the chiefs who descended from the Horites, the descendants of Seir in the land of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Lotan were Hori and Heman. Lotan’s sister was Timna.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the sons of Shobal: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah. This is the Anah who discovered the hot springs in the wilderness as he was feeding the donkeys of Zibeon his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the descendants of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Za’avan, and Akan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the chiefs who descended from the Horites: Chief Lotan, Chief Shobal, Chief Zibeon, Chief Anah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chief Dishon, Chief Ezer, and Chief Dishan. These are the chiefs who came from the Horites, according to their chiefdoms in the land of Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the people of Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bela son of Beor reigned in Edom. The name of his city was Dinhabah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bela died, and Jobab son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jobab died, and Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Husham died, and Hadad son of Bedad, who struck Midian in the territory of Moab, reigned in his place. The name of his city was Avith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadad died, and Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Samlah died, and Shaul of Rehoboth by the river reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shaul died, and Baal Hanan son of Achbor reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baal Hanan son of Achbor died, and Hadad reigned in his place. The name of his city was Pau. His wife’s name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Mezahab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following are the names of the chiefs who came from Esau, listed according to their clans, their territory, and their names: Chief Timna, Chief Alvah, Chief Jetheth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chief Oholibamah, Chief Elah, Chief Pinon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chief Kenaz, Chief Teman, Chief Mibzar,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chief Magdiel, and Chief Iram. These are the chiefs of Edom, according to the territory they inhabited in the land they possessed. (Edom is another name for Esau, the father of the Edomites.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob lived in the land where his father had resided as an alien, that is, in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account about the development of the family of Jacob:
When Joseph was seventeen years old, he was tending the flock with his brothers. He was just a boy compared to the sons of his father’s wives Bilhah and Zilpah. Joseph brought a bad report about them to their father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his other sons, because he was the son born in his old age, and he made him a special robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers saw that their father loved him more than all his brothers, so they hated him and could not speak to him in a friendly way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once Joseph had a dream, and he told it to his brothers, so they hated him all the more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Please listen to this dream that I have dreamed:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There we were, binding sheaves in the field, and suddenly my sheaf rose up and stood upright. Then your sheaves gathered around and bowed down to my sheaf.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers said to him, “So will you really reign over us? Will you really have dominion over us?” They hated him all the more because of his dreams and what he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he had another dream and told it to his brothers. He said, “Listen, I had another dream. This is what I saw: The sun and the moon and eleven stars bowed down to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told it to his father and to his brothers. His father rebuked him and said to him, “What kind of dream is this that you have dreamed? Will I and your mother and your brothers really come and bow down to the ground in front of you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept what he had said in mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers went to pasture their father’s flock in Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Israel said to Joseph, “Aren’t your brothers pasturing the flock in Shechem? Go, I will send you to them.”
Joseph said to him, “Yes, I will do it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to him, “Please go and see whether everything is going well with your brothers and with the flock. Then bring me word again.” So he sent him off from the valley at Hebron, and he arrived at Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man met him as he was wandering in the countryside. The man asked him, “What are you looking for?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “I am looking for my brothers. Tell me, please, where they are pasturing the flock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The man said, “They have left here. I heard them say, ‘Let’s go to Dothan.’”
Joseph went after his brothers and found them at Dothan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They saw him in the distance, and before he came near to them, they conspired against him to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to each other, “Look, here comes this master of dreams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come on, let’s kill him and throw him into one of the cisterns, and we will say, ‘A wild animal has devoured him.’ Then we will see what will become of his dreams.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben heard this and rescued him out of their hands. He said, “Let’s not take his life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben said to them, “Shed no blood. Throw him into this cistern that is in the wilderness, but do not lay a hand on him.” He said this so that he could rescue him out of their hands and restore him to his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so when Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped him of his robe, the special robe he was wearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took him and threw him into the cistern. The cistern was empty; there was no water in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sat down to eat bread, and they looked up and saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead with their camels loaded with spices, balm, and myrrh, which they were going to deliver to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah said to his brothers, “What profit is there in killing our brother and concealing his blood?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come on, let’s sell him to the Ishmaelites and not lay a hand on him, since he is our brother, our own flesh.” His brothers listened to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Midianites, who were merchants, were passing by, the brothers pulled Joseph up out of the cistern and sold Joseph to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. They brought Joseph to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Reuben returned to the cistern, he saw that Joseph was not in the cistern, so he tore his clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He returned to his brothers and said, “The boy is no longer here, and as for me, where will I go now?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took Joseph’s robe, killed a male goat, and dipped the robe in the goat’s blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took the special robe, and they brought it to their father and said, “We have found this. Examine it now, and see whether it is your son’s robe or not.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He recognized it and said, “It is my son’s robe. A wild animal has devoured him. Without a doubt Joseph has been torn to pieces.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob tore his clothing, put sackcloth around his waist, and mourned for his son for many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his sons and all his daughters rose up to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. He said, “No, I will mourn for my son until I go down to the grave.” So his father wept for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Egypt the Midianites sold him to Potiphar, an officer of Pharaoh, who was the captain of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About that time Judah went down from his brothers and visited a man from Adullam named Hirah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Judah saw a daughter of a Canaanite man named Shua. He took her as a wife and went to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived and gave birth to a son, and he named him Er.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She conceived again and gave birth to another son, and she named him Onan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She gave birth to yet another son and named him Shelah. It was at Kezib that she gave birth to Shelah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah took a wife for Er, his firstborn. Her name was Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It turned out that Er, Judah’s firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the Lord, so the Lord killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said to Onan, “Go to your brother’s wife. Perform your duty for her as the brother of her deceased husband and provide offspring for your brother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Onan knew that the offspring would not be his, so whenever he went to his brother’s wife, he wasted his semen on the ground, so that he would not provide offspring for his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the thing that he did was evil in the sight of the Lord, so the Lord killed him also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said to Tamar, his daughter-in-law, “Remain a widow in your father’s house until my son Shelah is grown up.” Actually he had said to himself, “I do not want him to die like his brothers.” So Tamar went and lived in her father’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After some time Shua’s daughter, the wife of Judah, died. When Judah had finished mourning, he went up to his sheepshearers at Timnah, he and his friend Hirah the Adullamite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tamar was told, “Look, your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She took off the garments that identified her as a widow, covered herself with her veil, disguised herself, and sat in the gate of Enaim, which is on the way to Timnah, because she saw that Shelah had grown up, but she was not going to be given to him as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Judah saw her, he thought that she was a prostitute, because she had covered her face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He turned to her by the roadside and said, “Please, let me come to you,” because he did not know that she was his daughter-in-law.
She said, “What will you give me, so that you may come to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “I will send you a young goat from the flock.”
She said, “Will you give me something as a security deposit until you send the goat?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “What should I give you as a deposit?”
She said, “Your stamp seal on its cord and your staff that is in your hand.”
He gave them to her and went to her, and she conceived by him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she got up and left. Later she took off her veil and put her widow’s garments back on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah sent the young goat with his friend, the Adullamite, to get back the deposit from the woman’s possession, but he could not find her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he asked the men from that place, “Where is the sacred prostitute who was by the road at Enaim?”
They said, “There hasn’t been any sacred prostitute here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he returned to Judah and said, “I could not find her, and the men of the place said, ‘There hasn’t been any sacred prostitute here.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah said, “Let her keep it, so that we are not disgraced. Look, I did send this young goat, but you were unable to find her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
About three months later Judah was told, “Tamar, your daughter-in-law, has prostituted herself, and even worse, she is pregnant by prostitution.”
Judah said, “Bring her out and burn her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she was brought, she sent this message to her father-in-law: “I am pregnant by the man to whom these things belong.” She also said, “Please help me identify whose these are—this stamp seal on its cord and the staff.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah recognized them and said, “She is more righteous than I, because I did not give her to Shelah, my son.” But he was not intimate with her again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the time came for her to go into labor, it turned out that there were twins in her womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she was in labor, one of the twins put out a hand, and the midwife took a scarlet thread and tied it on his hand, saying, “This one came out first.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then after he had pulled back his hand, his brother came out first, so she said, “What a breakthrough you made for yourself!” That is why he was named Perez.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward his brother who had the scarlet thread on his hand came out, so he was named Zerah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph was brought down to Egypt, Potiphar the Egyptian, who was an officer of Pharaoh and the captain of the guard, bought Joseph from the Ishmaelites who had brought him down to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was with Joseph, and he became successful. He served in the house of his master the Egyptian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His master saw that the Lord was with him, and that the Lord made everything that he touched a success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph found favor in his sight. Joseph served him, and he made Joseph manager of his household. He put Joseph in charge of everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the time that Potiphar made him manager of his household, in charge of everything that he had, the Lord blessed the Egyptian’s household for Joseph’s sake, and the blessing of the Lord rested on everything that he had, both in the house and in the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he left Joseph in charge of everything that he had. He did not concern himself with anything except the food that he ate.
Joseph was well built and handsome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sometime after all this, his master’s wife had her eye on Joseph, and she said, “Come, lie down with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he refused and said to his master’s wife, “Look, my master does not concern himself with anything that has been entrusted to me in the house. He has put me in charge of everything that he has.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has no one in this house greater than I am, and he has not withheld anything from me except you, because you are his wife. How then could I do such a great evil and sin against God?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She kept speaking to Joseph day after day, but he would not listen to her. He would not lie down beside her or even be with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But one day when he went into the house to do his work, none of the men of the household were there inside the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She caught him by his garment and said, “Come, lie down with me!” He left behind his garment in her hand and ran outside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she saw that he had left his garment in her hand and had run outside,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: she called to the men of her household and said to them, “Look, my husband has brought a Hebrew man in to put us to shame. He came in to lie down with me, but I screamed loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he heard me scream, he left behind his garment with me and ran outside.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She kept his garment beside her until his master came home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what she told him: “The Hebrew servant, whom you have brought to us, came to me to put me to shame and said to me, ‘Let me lie down with you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And look, when I screamed and cried out, he left behind his garment with me and ran outside.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as his master heard the words that his wife spoke to him, saying, “This is what your servant did to me,” he became very angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph’s master took him and put him into the prison where the king’s prisoners were confined, so Joseph was kept in prison there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord was with Joseph. He showed mercy to him and gave him favor in the sight of the warden of the prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The warden of the prison made Joseph responsible for all the prisoners who were in the prison. Joseph was responsible for whatever they did there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The warden of the prison did not pay attention to anything that was under his authority, because the Lord was with Joseph, and the Lord made everything that he did succeed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sometime after this, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt committed an offense against their lord, the king of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh was angry with his two officers, the chief cupbearer and the chief baker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put them under custody in the house of the captain of the guard, in the prison, the place where Joseph was confined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The captain of the guard assigned them to Joseph, and he was responsible for them. They stayed in prison for some time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were confined in the prison, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt each had a dream. Each man had his own dream during the same night. Each man’s dream had its own meaning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph came to them in the morning, looked at them, and saw that they were troubled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked Pharaoh’s officers who were in custody with him in his master’s house, “Why do you look so troubled today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They said to him, “We each had a dream, but there is no one who can interpret it.”
Joseph said to them, “Interpretations belong to God, don’t they? Please tell me the dreams.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The chief cupbearer told Joseph his dream. “In my dream, there was a vine in front of me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the vine had three branches. As I watched, it budded, it blossomed, and its clusters produced ripe grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I had Pharaoh’s cup in my hand. I took the grapes, pressed them into Pharaoh’s cup, and handed the cup to Pharaoh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to him, “This is its interpretation: The three branches are three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Within three days, Pharaoh will lift up your head and restore you to your office. You will place Pharaoh’s cup into his hand, the way you used to do when you were his cupbearer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But remember me when everything is going well for you. Please show kindness to me, and mention me to Pharaoh, and bring me out of this jail,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because I was kidnapped from the land of the Hebrews, and I also have done nothing here to deserve to be put into the dungeon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was favorable, he said to Joseph, “I also had a dream. I saw three baskets of white bread on my head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the top basket there were all kinds of baked goods for Pharaoh, but the birds ate them out of the basket on my head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph answered, “This is its interpretation: The three baskets are three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Within three days, Pharaoh will lift up your head from upon you and will hang you on a tree, and the birds will eat your flesh off of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so it was that on the third day, which was Pharaoh’s birthday, Pharaoh had a feast prepared for all his officials, and he lifted up the head of the chief cupbearer and the head of the chief baker among his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He restored the chief cupbearer to his position again, and he again placed the cup into Pharaoh’s hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he hanged the chief baker, just as Joseph had explained to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, the chief cupbearer did not remember Joseph, but forgot him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of two full years Pharaoh also had a dream. In the dream he was standing beside the river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There, right in front of him, seven beautiful, fat cows came up out of the river and were grazing in the marsh grass.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then seven ugly, thin cows came up out of the river behind them, and they stood beside the other cows on the bank of the river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ugly, thin cows ate up the seven beautiful, fat cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh fell asleep again and dreamed a second time. He saw seven healthy, good heads of grain come up on one stalk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Right after that, seven thin heads of grain, blasted by the east wind, sprang up after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven healthy, full heads. Pharaoh woke up and realized that it was a dream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning he was very troubled, so he sent for all of Egypt’s magicians and wise men. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but there was no one who could interpret them for Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the chief cupbearer said to Pharaoh, “Today I remember my faults.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh was angry with his servants and put me in custody in the house of the captain of the guard—me and the chief baker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We each had a dream during the same night—he and I. Each of us dreamed a dream that had its own interpretation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a young man with us, a Hebrew, a servant to the captain of the guard, and we told him our dreams, and he interpreted our dreams for us. To each man he gave the interpretation of his dream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It turned out exactly as he interpreted them for us. Pharaoh restored me to my office but hanged the chief baker.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh sent for Joseph, and they brought him quickly out of the dungeon. Joseph shaved, changed his clothing, and went to Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I had a dream, and there is no one who can interpret it. I have heard it said about you, that when you hear a dream, you can interpret it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph answered Pharaoh, “It is not in my power. God will give Pharaoh an answer to give him peace of mind.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh spoke to Joseph: “In my dream, there I was, standing on the bank of the river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly seven fat, beautiful cows came up out of the river and were grazing in the marsh grass.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then seven poor cattle, very ugly and thin, came up after them. They were uglier than any I had ever seen in the whole land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The thin, ugly cattle ate up the first seven cattle, the fat ones,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and when they had eaten them up, you could not even tell that they had eaten them, because they were still as ugly as they were at the beginning. Then I woke up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Later I had another dream, in which I saw seven heads of grain grow on one stalk. They were full and good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I saw seven heads of grain spring up after them. They were withered, thin, and blasted by the east wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven good heads of grain. I told the dream to the magicians, but there was no one who could explain it to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to Pharaoh, “The dream of Pharaoh is one. God has declared to Pharaoh what he is about to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven good cattle are seven years, and the seven good heads of grain are seven years. It is one dream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven thin, ugly cattle that came up after them are seven years, and also the seven empty heads of grain blasted by the east wind. They will be seven years of famine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the very thing that I told Pharaoh: God has shown Pharaoh what he is about to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, seven years of great abundance are coming throughout the whole land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven years of famine will come up after them, and all the abundance in the land of Egypt will be forgotten. The famine will consume the land,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the abundance will not be remembered in the land because of the famine that follows, for it will be very severe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The double dream was shown to Pharaoh, because this matter is established by God, and God will bring it to pass very soon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Let Pharaoh, therefore, look for a man who is wise and discerning, and set him over the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh does this, let him appoint overseers over the land to collect one fifth of the produce of the land of Egypt during the seven years of abundance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let them collect all this food from these good years that are coming. Accumulate grain under the authority of Pharaoh to provide food for the cities, and let them store it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The food will be a reserve for the land against the seven years of famine that will take place in the land of Egypt so that the land does not perish because of the famine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The plan seemed good to Pharaoh and to all his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to his officials, “Can we find anyone else like this man, a man who has the spirit of God?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Because God has shown you all of this, there is no one as discerning and wise as you are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall be in charge of my house, and all my people will submit to your word. Only in regard to the throne will I be greater than you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh also said to Joseph, “Look, I have appointed you over the whole land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh took his signet ring off of his hand and put it on Joseph’s hand. He dressed Joseph in robes made from the best linen and put a gold chain around his neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had him ride in the second best chariot that he had. Men went ahead of him crying out, “Kneel down!” Pharaoh appointed him over the whole land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh, but in the whole land of Egypt no one will lift up his hand or his foot without your permission.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh gave Joseph the name Zaphenath Paneah, and he gave him Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, as a wife. Joseph went out and began to rule over the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh king of Egypt. Joseph went out from the presence of Pharaoh and traveled throughout the whole land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the seven years of abundance the earth produced plentiful harvests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He collected all the food during the seven good years in the land of Egypt, and he stored up the food in the cities. In every city he stored the food from the fields that were around the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph stored up a huge amount of grain, like the sand of the sea. Finally he stopped keeping track, because it was too much to measure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two sons were born to Joseph before the first year of famine arrived. Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, gave birth to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph named the firstborn Manasseh, because he said, “God has made me forget all my trouble and all my father’s house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He named the second son Ephraim. He said, “Yes, God has made me fruitful in the land where I was afflicted.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the seven years of abundance in the land of Egypt came to an end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had said. There was famine in every land, but in the whole land of Egypt there was bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the whole land of Egypt was starving, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread, and Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, “Go to Joseph. Do whatever he tells you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The famine spread over the face of the whole earth. Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians. The famine was severe in the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole world came to Joseph in Egypt to buy grain, because the famine was severe all over the whole world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob heard that there was grain in Egypt, he said to his sons, “Why are you standing here looking at each other?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also said, “Listen, I have heard that there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy some for us there, so that we may live and not die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So ten of Joseph’s brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob did not send Joseph’s brother Benjamin along with his other brothers, because he said, “Something bad might happen to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Israel were among those who came to buy grain because of the famine in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph was the governor over the land. He was the one who sold grain to all the people of the land. Joseph’s brothers came and bowed down to him with their faces to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joseph saw his brothers and recognized them, but he acted like a stranger toward them and spoke harshly to them. He asked them, “Where did you come from?”
They said, “From the land of Canaan to buy food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph recognized his brothers, but they did not recognize him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph remembered the dreams that he had dreamed about them and said to them, “You are spies! You have come to see where the land is exposed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “No, my lord, your servants have come to buy food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are all one man’s sons. We are honest men. Your servants are not spies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “No, you have come to see where the land is exposed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “We, your servants, are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan. Listen, at the present time the youngest remains with our father, and one is no more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to them, “It is just as I said. You are spies!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how you will be tested: By the life of Pharaoh, you shall never get out of here, unless your youngest brother comes here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Send one of you to get your brother. The rest of you will be kept under arrest, so that your words may be tested, whether you are telling the truth. Otherwise, by the life of Pharaoh, you are spies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He kept them all together, confined in the jail for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day Joseph said to them, “Do what I tell you and you will live, because I fear God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you are honest men, let one of your brothers be confined in the jail, but the rest of you go and deliver grain to your houses to relieve the famine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring your youngest brother to me so that your words may be verified, and you will not die.” So they did as he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to one another, “We are certainly guilty concerning our brother, because we saw the misery of his soul when he begged us, but we would not listen. That is why this misery has come upon us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben answered them, “Didn’t I tell you, ‘Do not sin against the boy’? But you would not listen. So now payment for his blood is being required from us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They did not know that Joseph understood them, because an interpreter was being used between them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph turned away from them and wept. After he returned and spoke to them, he seized Simeon from among them and tied him up before their very eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph gave a command to fill their containers with grain, to return each man’s money into his sack, and to give them food for the journey. So all this was done for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They loaded their donkeys with their grain and departed from there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When one of them opened his sack at the lodging place to give his donkey food, he saw his money. It was right there in the mouth of his bag.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his brothers, “My money has been returned! Look, there it is, in my bag!” Their hearts sank, and they turned to one another trembling and said, “What is this that God has done to us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came to Jacob their father in the land of Canaan and told him everything that had happened to them. They said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The man, the lord of the land, spoke harshly to us and accused us of being spies against the country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We said to him, ‘We are honest men. We are not spies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are twelve brothers, sons of our father. One brother is no more, and at the present time the youngest is with our father in the land of Canaan.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That man, the lord of the land, said to us, ‘This is how I will know that you are honest men: Leave one of your brothers with me. Take grain to relieve the famine at your houses, and go on your way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring your youngest brother to me. Then I will know that you are not spies, but that you are honest men. Then I will release your brother to you, and you will be allowed to conduct business in the land.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then as they emptied their sacks, they were surprised to see that each man’s pouch of money was in his sack. When they and their father saw their pouch of money, they were afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob, their father, said to them, “You have deprived me of my children! Joseph is no more. Simeon is no more. And now you want to take Benjamin away. All these things are against me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben spoke to his father, “You may put my two sons to death if I do not bring him back to you. Entrust him to my care, and I will bring him back to you again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said, “My son shall not go down with you, since his brother is dead, and he alone is left. If he has a mishap on the journey that you are taking, you will bring my gray hairs down to the grave with sorrow.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The famine in the land was severe,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so when they had eaten all the grain that they had brought from Egypt, their father said to them, “Go back and buy a little more food for us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah said to him, “The man sternly warned us, ‘You shall not see my face unless your brother is with you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you send our brother with us, we will go down and buy food for you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but if you do not send him, we will not go down, because the man said to us, ‘You shall not see my face unless your brother is with you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said, “Why did you treat me so badly by telling the man that you had another brother?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “The man interrogated us about ourselves and about our relatives. He asked, ‘Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?’ We just answered his questions. Is there any way we could have known that he would say, ‘Bring your brother down here’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah said to his father Israel, “Send the boy with me, and we will get up and go, so that we may live and not die, both we and you and also our little ones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will serve as a guarantee for him. You can hold me accountable for him. If I do not bring him back to you and set him in front of you, then let me bear the blame forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, if we had not delayed, we certainly could have returned for a second time by now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their father Israel said to them, “If it must be so, then this is what you should do: Put some of the best products of the land into your containers and take a gift for the man: a little balm, a little honey, spices and myrrh, pistachios and almonds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also take double the amount of silver with you. Take back the silver that was returned into the mouths of your bags. Perhaps it was an oversight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also take your brother. Get going and return to the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God Almighty grant you mercy before the man, so that he will release your other brother and Benjamin to you. But if I am deprived of my children, I am deprived.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men took that present, and they took double the amount of silver with them. They also took Benjamin. They got up, went down to Egypt, and stood before Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the manager of his house, “Bring the men into the house. Butcher an animal and prepare it, for the men will dine with me at noon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The manager did as Joseph commanded and brought the men to Joseph’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The brothers were afraid, because they were brought to Joseph’s house. They said, “Because of the money that was returned into our bags the first time, we are being brought in, so that he may find a pretext against us, pounce on us, seize us as slaves, and take our donkeys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They approached the manager of Joseph’s house and spoke to him at the door of the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “Please, my lord, we really did come down the first time to buy food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we came to the lodging place, we opened our bags, and to our surprise each man’s silver was in the mouth of his bag, the full amount of our money. We have brought it back with us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have also brought down with us additional money to buy food. We do not know who put our money into our bags.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “There is no problem. Do not be afraid. Your God, the God of your father, has given you treasure in your bags. I received your money.” He brought Simeon out to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man brought the men into Joseph’s house and gave them water, so they could wash their feet. He gave their donkeys fodder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They prepared the gift for Joseph, who was coming at noon, because they heard that they would be eating bread there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph came home, they presented him with the gift that they had brought to the house, and they bowed down to the ground in front of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked them about their welfare: “Is your father well, the old man of whom you spoke? Is he still alive?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “Your servant, our father, is well. He is still alive.” They bowed down and prostrated themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph looked up and saw Benjamin, his brother, his mother’s son, and he asked, “Is this your youngest brother, the one you told me about?” He said, “God be gracious to you, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph hurried out, because he was overcome by his emotions over his brother, and he looked for a place to weep. He went into his room and wept there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he washed his face and came out. After he regained control of himself, he said, “Serve the meal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They served Joseph by himself, the brothers by themselves, and the Egyptians who ate with him by themselves, because the Egyptians do not eat with Hebrews, for that is repulsive to the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The brothers were seated in front of him. They were lined up in order, starting with the firstborn based on his birthright down to the youngest based on his youth, and the men expressed their amazement to each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent servings to them from his table, but Benjamin’s portion was five times as much as any of theirs. They were drinking and they were feeling the effects.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph commanded the manager of his house, “Fill the men’s bags with food, as much as they can carry. Put each man’s money into the mouth of his bag.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put my cup, the silver cup, into the mouth of the bag of the youngest, along with his money for the grain.” The manager did exactly what Joseph told him to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as it became light in the morning, the men were sent on their way, with their donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had left the city and still were not very far away, Joseph said to his manager, “Get up. Pursue those men. When you overtake them, ask them, ‘Why have you repaid evil for good?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t this the cup that my lord drinks from and that he uses for divination? By doing this you have done evil.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The steward caught up to them and spoke those words to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied to him, “Why does my lord say such things? Your servants would never do such a thing!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That money, which we found in the mouths of our bags—we brought it back to you from the land of Canaan. Why then would we steal silver or gold out of your lord’s house?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If your cup is found with any of your servants, let him die, and we also will be my lord’s slaves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Fine, it will be just as you have said. If it is found with anyone, he will be my slave, and the rest of you will be blameless.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then each man quickly lowered his bag to the ground, and each man opened his bag.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The manager searched, beginning with the oldest and finishing with the youngest, and the cup was found in Benjamin’s bag.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they tore their clothing, and each man loaded his donkey and returned to the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Judah and his brothers came to Joseph’s house, he was still there. They fell to the ground before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to them, “What did you think you were doing? Didn’t you know that a man like me can discover things by divination?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah said, “What can we tell my lord? What can we say? How can we clear ourselves? God has exposed the guilt of your servants. Here we are. We are my lord’s slaves, both we and the one in whose hand the cup was found.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said, “I would never do that. The man in whose hand the cup was found will be my slave, but as for the rest of you, go up in peace to your father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah approached him and said, “O my lord, please let your servant speak to my lord directly. Do not let your anger burn against your servant, because you are just like Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My lord asked his servants, ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We said to my lord, ‘We have a father, an old man, and a child from his old age, a young one. His brother is dead, and he alone is left from his mother, and his father loves him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You said to your servants, ‘Bring him down to me, so that I may see him with my own eyes.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We said to my lord, ‘The boy cannot leave his father, for if he were to leave his father, his father would die.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You said to your servants, ‘Unless your youngest brother comes down with you, you will never see my face again.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so it was that when we came to your servant, my father, we told him about the words of my lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our father said, ‘Go again. Buy us a little food.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We said, ‘We cannot go down. If our youngest brother is with us, we will go down, because we cannot see the man’s face unless our youngest brother is with us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant, my father, said to us, ‘You know that my wife gave birth to two sons for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The one has departed from me and I said, “I am sure he is torn to pieces,” and I have not seen him since.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you take this one away from me as well, and mishap comes upon him, you will bring my gray hairs down to the grave with sorrow.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now when I come to your servant my father, and the boy is not with us, since my father’s life is bound up in the boy’s life,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when he sees that the boy is no more, he will die. Your servants will bring down the gray hairs of your servant, our father, to the grave with sorrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your servant became a guarantee for the boy to my father. I said, ‘If I do not bring him to you, then I will bear the blame before my father forever.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So please let your servant stay as a slave to my lord instead of the boy, and let the boy go up with his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For how can I go up to my father if the boy is not with me? How could I stand to see the evil that will come on my father?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph was unable to control himself in front of all his attendants, so he called out, “Send everyone out from my presence!” When no one else was left with him, Joseph revealed himself to his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He wept out loud. The Egyptians heard him, and the house of Pharaoh heard about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph! Is my father still alive?”
His brothers could not answer him, because they were terrified by his presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joseph said to his brothers, “Come closer to me, please.”
They came closer. He said, “I am Joseph, your brother, whom you sold into Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now do not be upset or angry with yourselves for selling me to this place, since God sent me ahead of you to preserve life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For two years now the famine has been in the land, and there are still five more years in which there will be neither plowing nor harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God sent me ahead of you to preserve you as survivors on the earth, and to keep you alive by a great act of deliverance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So it was not you who sent me here, but God, and he has made me a father to Pharaoh, lord over his entire household, and ruler over the whole land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hurry, go up to my father and tell him, ‘This is what your son Joseph says: “God has made me lord of all Egypt. Come down to me. Do not delay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall live in the land of Goshen, where you will be close to me—you, your children, your grandchildren, your flocks, your herds, and all that you have.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take care of you here, for there are still five years of famine. Otherwise you will come to ruin, you, and your household, and all that you have.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pay attention. Your eyes and the eyes of my brother Benjamin see that it is my mouth that speaks to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall tell my father all about my position of honor in Egypt and about everything that you have seen. Hurry and bring my father down here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He threw his arms around his brother Benjamin’s neck and wept, and Benjamin wept on his shoulder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He kissed all his brothers and wept over them. After that his brothers talked with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This report was heard in Pharaoh’s house: “Joseph’s brothers have come.” This pleased Pharaoh and his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Tell your brothers, ‘Load your animals. Travel quickly to the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get your father and your households, and return to me, and I will give you the best of the land of Egypt, and you will eat the rich food of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I command you to do this: Take carts from the land of Egypt for your little ones and your wives, and bring your father here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, do not worry about your belongings, for the best of the whole land of Egypt is yours.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that is what the sons of Israel did. Joseph gave them carts as Pharaoh had commanded, and he gave them supplies for the journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gave each one of them a change of clothing, but to Benjamin he gave three hundred pieces of silver and five changes of clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent the following to his father: ten donkeys loaded with the best things of Egypt, and ten female donkeys loaded with grain and bread and supplies for his father on the journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he dismissed his brothers, and they departed. He said to them, “See to it that you do not quarrel on the way.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went up from Egypt and came to Jacob their father in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “Joseph is still alive, and he is ruler over all the land of Egypt.” He was stunned because he did not believe them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told Jacob every word that Joseph had said to them. When he saw the carts that Joseph had sent to carry him, the spirit of their father Jacob revived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said, “It is enough. Joseph my son is still alive. I will go and see him before I die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel traveled with all that he had until he came to Beersheba, where he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God called to Israel in a vision at night, “Jacob, Jacob!”
Jacob said, “I am here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “I am God, the God of your father. Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for there I will make you into a great nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will go down to Egypt with you, and I will certainly bring you back again. And Joseph’s hand will close your eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob set out from Beersheba, and the sons of Israel transported Jacob their father, their little ones, and their wives in the carts that Pharaoh had sent to transport him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took their livestock and their property that they had acquired in the land of Canaan and came into Egypt—Jacob, and all his offspring with him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: his sons and his grandsons, his daughters and his granddaughters. So he brought all his offspring with him into Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the names of the sons of Israel who came to Egypt, that is, Jacob and his sons:
Reuben was Jacob’s firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Reuben were Hanoch,
Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and
Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Judah were Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah, but Er
and Onan had died in the land of Canaan. The sons of Perez were
Hezron and Hamul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Issachar were Tola, Puvah, Iob, and Shimron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Zebulun were Sered, Elon, and Jahle’el.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those are the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan
Aram, along with his daughter Dinah. The total number of souls of
his sons and his daughters was thirty-three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Gad were Ziphion, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi,
and Areli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, and Serah
their sister. The sons of Beriah were Heber and Malchiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to Leah, his
daughter, and Zilpah bore these to Jacob, a total of sixteen souls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Rachel, Jacob’s wife, were Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Manasseh and Ephraim were born to Joseph in the land of Egypt.
Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, gave birth to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Benjamin were Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Na’aman,
Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the sons of
Rachel, who were born to Jacob. The total was fourteen souls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The son of Dan was Hushim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Naphtali were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to Rachel,
his daughter, and these she bore to Jacob. The total was seven souls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total number of souls who came with Jacob into Egypt, who were his direct descendants, besides Jacob’s sons’ wives, was sixty-six.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Joseph, who were born to him in Egypt, were two souls.
The total number of the souls in the house of Jacob who came into Egypt was seventy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob sent Judah ahead of him to Joseph to lead the way to Goshen. And so they arrived in the land of Goshen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph prepared his chariot and went to meet Israel his father in Goshen. He approached him, hugged him, and wept on his shoulder for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, “Now I am ready to die, since I have seen you face-to-face and you are still alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to his brothers and to his father’s family, “I will go up and speak with Pharaoh. I will tell him, ‘My brothers and my father’s household, who were in the land of Canaan, have come to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men are shepherds. They make their living taking care of livestock, and they have brought with them their flocks and their herds, and all that they have.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what you should say when Pharaoh summons you and asks, ‘What is your occupation?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall say, ‘Your servants have been keepers of livestock from our youth even until now, both we and our fathers.’ Ask for the right to live in the land of Goshen, for every shepherd is repulsive to the Egyptians.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph went and told Pharaoh, “My father and my brothers have come from the land of Canaan with their flocks, their herds, and all that they own, and now they are in the land of Goshen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took five of his brothers and presented them to Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh said to his brothers, “What is your occupation?”
They answered Pharaoh, “Your servants are shepherds, both we and our fathers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Pharaoh, “We have come to reside as aliens in the land, for your servants have no pasture for their flocks, because the famine is severe in the land of Canaan. Now therefore, please let your servants dwell in the land of Goshen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh responded to Joseph, “Your father and your brothers have come to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land of Egypt is open to you. Arrange for your father and your brothers to dwell in the best of the land. Let them settle in the land of Goshen. If you know any capable men among them, then put them in charge of my livestock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph brought Jacob his father and presented him to Pharaoh, and Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Jacob, “How many are the days and the years of your life?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to Pharaoh, “The days and the years of my wandering are one hundred thirty years. The days and the years of my life have been few and full of trouble, and they have not been as many as the days and the years of the lives of my fathers during the days of their wandering.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went out from the presence of Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph settled his father and his brothers and gave them property in the land of Egypt, in the best part of the land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph provided his father, his brothers, and all of his father’s household with food, based on the number in their families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no food in all the land because the famine was very severe, so that the land of Egypt and the land of Canaan grew weak because of the famine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph collected all the money that was found in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan as payment for the grain that they purchased, and Joseph brought the money into Pharaoh’s palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the money in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan had been spent, all the Egyptians came to Joseph and said, “Give us bread, for why should we die right in front of your eyes? Look, our money is running out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph said, “Give me your livestock, and I will give you food for your livestock if your money is gone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought their livestock to Joseph, and Joseph gave them food in exchange for the horses, and for the flocks, and for the herds, and for the donkeys. He supplied them with food for that year in exchange for all their livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that year was ended, they came to him during the second year and said to him, “We will not hide from my lord the fact that our money is all spent, and the herds of livestock belong to my lord. My lord can see that we have nothing left but our bodies and our lands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should we die right in front of your eyes, both we and our land? Purchase us and our land in exchange for bread, and we along with our land will serve Pharaoh. Give us seed, so that we may live and not die, so that the land will not be desolate.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph purchased all the land in Egypt for Pharaoh, because every man among the Egyptians sold his field, because the famine had them in its grip, and the land became Pharaoh’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the people, he made them all servants from one end of the territory of Egypt all the way to the other end of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land that belonged to the priests was the only land that he did not purchase, because the priests had a regular allotment from Pharaoh and ate from the allotment that Pharaoh gave them. That is why they did not sell their land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said to the people, “Since I have purchased you and your land today for Pharaoh, here is seed for you to sow the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what you shall do at the harvests: Give a fifth to Pharaoh, and four fifths will be your own share, which you can use as seed to sow the field and as food for yourselves, for everyone in your household, and for your little ones.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “You have saved our lives! Let us find favor in the sight of my lord, and we will be Pharaoh’s servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph made it a regulation concerning the farmland in Egypt to this day, that Pharaoh should receive a fifth of the produce. Only the land of the priests did not become Pharaoh’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel lived in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen, and they acquired possessions for themselves there. They were fruitful and multiplied greatly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob lived in the land of Egypt for seventeen years. So the days of Jacob, the years of his life, were one hundred forty-seven years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The time drew near that Israel must die, so he called his son Joseph and said to him, “If now I have found favor in your sight, please put your hand under my thigh and deal kindly and truthfully with me. Please do not bury me in Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but when I rest with my fathers, you are to carry me out of Egypt and bury me in their burial place.”
He said, “I will do as you have said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Swear to me,” and he swore to him. Israel bowed himself on the head post of the bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator
