verses.text: Sometime after these things Joseph was told, “Come right away. Your father is sick.” So he took his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim, with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob was told, “Look, your son Joseph is coming to you,” so Israel gathered his strength and sat up on the bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to Joseph, “God Almighty appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan and blessed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to me, ‘I will make you fruitful and multiply you, and I will make you into a community of peoples, and I will give this land to your descendants after you as a permanent possession.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now your two sons, who were born to you in the land of Egypt before I came to you in Egypt, will be counted as mine. Ephraim and Manasseh will count as my sons the same as Reuben and Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your sons that you father after them will count as your own. For receiving their inheritance they will be registered under the name of their brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for me, when I came back from Paddan, to my loss Rachel died on the journey in the land of Canaan when we were still some distance from Ephrath, and I buried her there on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel saw Joseph’s sons and asked, “Who are these boys?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joseph said to his father, “They are my sons, whom God has given me here.”
Israel said, “Please bring them to me, and I will bless them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the eyes of Israel were failing because of his age, and he could not see. Joseph brought the boys close to Jacob, and he kissed them and embraced them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, “I did not think I would see your face, but now God has let me see your offspring also.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph moved them from Jacob’s lap, and he bowed down with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph led them both. He led Ephraim with his right hand toward Israel’s left hand, and Manasseh with his left hand toward Israel’s right hand, and brought them close to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Israel, crossing his hands, stretched out his right hand and laid it on the head of Ephraim, who was the younger, and his left hand on Manasseh’s head, though Manasseh was the firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He blessed Joseph and said,
May the God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked,
the God who has been my shepherd all my life to this day,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the Angel who has redeemed me from all evil,
bless these lads,
and let my name be placed on them,
and the name of my fathers Abraham and Isaac.
Let them grow into a multitude in the midst of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph saw that his father laid his right hand on the head of Ephraim, he was displeased. He held up his father’s hand to remove it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to his father, “Not so, my father, for this one is the firstborn. Put your right hand on his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His father refused and said, “I know, my son. I know. He also will become a people, and he also will be great. However, his younger brother will be greater than he, and his descendants will become a multitude of nations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He blessed them that day with these words: “Israel will pronounce a blessing using your name, saying, ‘May God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh.’” So he placed Ephraim ahead of Manasseh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, “You see that I am dying, but God will be with you and will bring you again to the land of your fathers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, I have given to you one share more than your brothers: the ridge of Shechem that I took out of the hand of the Amorites with my sword and with my bow.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob called his sons and said, “Gather together, so that I can declare to you what will happen to you in the days to come.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Assemble together, and listen to this, you sons of Jacob.
Listen to Israel, your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Reuben, you are my firstborn, my might,
and the beginning of my vigor,
excelling in dignity and excelling in power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Boiling over like water, you shall not excel,
because you went up to your father’s bed,
and you defiled it.
He went up to my couch!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Simeon and Levi are brothers.
Their daggers are weapons of violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My soul, do not enter their council.
My glory, do not join in their assembly.
Yes, in their anger they killed men.
In their spitefulness they hamstrung oxen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cursed be their anger, for it was fierce.
Cursed be their wrath, for it was cruel.
I will divide them in Jacob.
I will scatter them in Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Judah, your brothers will praise you.
Your hand will be on the throat of your enemies.
Your father’s sons will bow down to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Judah is a lion’s cub.
You have gone up from the prey, my son.
He stooped down. He crouched like a lion.
He is like a lioness. Who will provoke him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The scepter will not depart from Judah,
nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet,
until the one to whom it belongs comes.
He will receive the obedience of the peoples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will tie his foal to the vine,
his donkey’s colt to the choice vine.
He has washed his clothing in wine,
his garments in the blood of grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His eyes will be darker than wine,
his teeth whiter than milk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Zebulun will dwell at the seashore.
He will provide a landing place for ships.
His border will extend toward Sidon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Issachar is a strong-boned donkey,
lying down between the saddlebags.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He saw a resting place that was good.
He saw land that was pleasant.
He bows his shoulder under the burden
and becomes a slave doing forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Dan will judge his people
as one of the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Dan will be a snake in the way,
a viper in the path.
It bites the horse’s heels,
so that its rider falls backward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have waited for your salvation, O Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Raiders will attack Gad,
but he will attack their heels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Asher’s food will be rich.
He will produce delicacies fit for a king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Naphtali is a doe set free,
that bears beautiful fawns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joseph is a fruitful vine,
a fruitful vine by a spring.
His branches run over the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The archers have fiercely attacked him.
They shot at him and harassed him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but his bow remained steady.
His arms and hands were made strong
by the hands of the Mighty One of Jacob,
by the name of the Shepherd, the Stone of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
by the God of your father, who will help you,
by the Almighty, who will bless you
with blessings from heaven above,
blessings from the deep that lies below,
blessings from the breasts and from the womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The blessings of your father are greater than the blessings of
    my parents,
greater than the treasures of the ancient hills.
They will rest on the head of Joseph,
on the forehead of him who is elevated above his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benjamin is a ravenous wolf.
In the morning he will devour the prey.
At evening he will divide the spoils.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father spoke to them when he blessed them. He blessed each one with the appropriate blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He instructed them and said to them, “I am going to be gathered to my people. Bury me with my fathers in the cave that is in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in the cave that is in the field at Machpelah, which is near Mamre in the land of Canaan, which Abraham purchased along with the field from Ephron the Hittite as a burial place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There they buried Abraham and Sarah his wife. There they buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife, and there I buried Leah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The field and the cave that is in it was purchased from the descendants of Heth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob finished instructing his sons, he gathered up his feet into the bed, breathed his last breath, and was gathered to his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph put his face against his father’s face, wept over him, and kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph commanded the physicians who served him to embalm his father, so the physicians embalmed Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Forty days were set aside for him, for that is how many days it takes to embalm. The Egyptians mourned for him for seventy days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the days of mourning for Jacob were past, Joseph spoke to the household of Pharaoh. He said, “If now I have found favor in your eyes, please speak directly to Pharaoh for me and say
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that my father made me take an oath. He said to me, ‘Look, I am dying. Bury me in my tomb that I have dug for myself in the land of Canaan.’ Now therefore, please let me go up and bury my father, and I will return here again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, “Go up and bury your father, just as he made you swear to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph went up to bury his father, and all the officials of Pharaoh went up with him: the senior officials of Pharaoh’s household, all the elders of the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the household of Joseph, his brothers, and his father’s household. Only their little ones, their flocks, and their herds were left in the land of Goshen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both chariots and horsemen went up with him. It was a very great entourage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came to the threshing floor of Atad, which is on the other side of the Jordan, and there they mourned with a very loud and bitter lament. Joseph mourned for his father seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, witnessed the mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, they said, “This is a very solemn mourning by the Egyptians.” That is why they named the place Abel Mizraim. It is beyond the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sons did for him just what he commanded them to do:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They carried him to the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave in the field at Machpelah, which Abraham had purchased along with the field. He purchased it from Ephron the Hittite, as a piece of property for a burial site near Mamre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had buried his father, Joseph returned to Egypt—he and his brothers, and all who had gone up with him to bury his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, “It may be that Joseph will hate us and will pay us back in full for all of the evil that we did to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sent the following message to Joseph: “Before he died your father commanded us,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
‘You are to tell Joseph, “Please forgive the offense of your brothers and their sin, because they did evil to you.”’ Now, please forgive the offense of the servants of the God of your father.”
Joseph wept when they spoke to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers also came and fell down in front of him, and they said, “See now, we are your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to them, “Do not be afraid, for am I in the place of God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You meant evil against me, but God meant it for good, to bring this to pass and to keep many people alive, as it is this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now therefore, do not be afraid. I will nourish you and your little ones.” He comforted them and spoke to them in a kind way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph lived in Egypt, he and his father’s household. Joseph lived one hundred ten years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He saw Ephraim’s children to the third generation. The children also of Makir, the son of Manasseh, were placed on Joseph’s knees when they were born.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am dying, but God will surely visit you and bring you up out of this land to the land that he swore to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph made the descendants of Israel swear an oath. He said, “God will surely visit you. Then you shall carry my bones up from here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph died when he was one hundred ten years old, and they embalmed him, and he was put in a coffin in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator
